product_title: Gore Bike Wear Men's Contest 2.0 Active Shell Jacket, Red/Black/White, Small
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Breathes well, great fit, quality construction and will keep you dry AND warm
review_title: Breathes well, great fit, quality construction and will keep you dry AND warm
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2013
review_body: I purchased this jacket for use riding in the rain and cold. The Gore Contest jacket will keep you very dry in the rain but what is even better is how it keeps stinging cold wind away from your body. I cycle in the winter using this jacket and a long sleeve jersey, and if it is cold enough, sometimes a thin wicking layer underneath it. Even cycling below freezing, when using layers this jacket is component to a superior system. During the early winter and late fall, it can be below 40 when I start my ride but heat up to the 50s. This jacket can be rolled down and placed in a rear pocket. It will completely fill one of your pockets but as long as you fold/roll neatly it fits perfectly.

product_title: Gore Bike Wear Men's Contest 2.0 Active Shell Jacket, Red/Black/White, Small
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good, but not great
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2013
review_body:
I've owned a few Gore jackets for biking and other sports (windstopper, GoreTEX, etc.) and I'm a bit disappointed by this jacket. It does not seem quite as well thought out as many of their other jackets. The Gore Windstopper fabric is still great quality though. It does what it's made out to be, for the most part, but I would not pay a cent more for it.

Pros
+ Small fits snug enough to not flutter, but loose enough to allow for some layering (I'm 5'6" and 145 lbs).
+ Repels a great deal of water (I was still dry even after a 3h ride with pretty much constant rain).
+ Breathable, as one would expect from Gore.
+ Lightweight.

Cons,
- White sections were no longer white after a single ride (unlike previous Gore windstopper jackets I've owned, the dirt did not wash off at all).
- Back pocket tends to hang out from under the jacket when the back rides up, and everything in the mesh pocket will get wet and muddy (don't put your phone in there without a ziploc bag to protect it!) - a simple fix would be to attach the bottom of the mesh pocket to the jacket.
- Back pocket zipper feels like its going to fall apart any minute.

product_title: Gore Bike Wear Men's Contest 2.0 Active Shell Jacket, Red/Black/White, Small
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Breathable, durable, packable, water resistant
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2013
review_body:
This is a good jacket for its intended use that is built to last. It's not the lightest and smallest but compresses down to easily fit in a jersey pocket (but don't plan on anything other than your house key in with it). The windstopper fabric reduces wind chill about 95%, and, even without any vents, the material is remarkably breathable so you aren't marinating in your own juices at the top of a climb. I can adequately regulate temperature by slightly opening the zipper pulling up the cuffs a bit (cuffs have both elastic and velcro so comfortable and will stay put). I wouldn't want to depend on this jacket in an extended downpour, but it has kept me dry in occasional showers and on a long ride in mist and drizzle on the Blue Ridge Parkway.

It's a good fit for general cycling but not super form fitting; however, this allows adequate room for layering and year-round use and it's comfortable off and on the bike. I'm 6', 175 lbs and find the large true to size with adequate length in the sleeves and tail. I can wear it over my soft-shell cycling jacket in winter but it isn't excessively loose over just a summer jersey. There is some wind noise on the descents but it doesn't puff up like a parachute. Another good example of quality and versatility I've found in most of the Gore Bike products.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Powerfly Down Puff Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Super lightweight and toasty, but stay out of the rain
review_title: Super lightweight and toasty, but stay out of the rain
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2012
review_body:
I've been wearing this for about a week now, which is not long enough to provide a thorough review, but seeing as how no one has reviewed it yet I thought I'd get some early info out there for anyone considering purchasing this jacket.

I've been wearing it in mid-40's and windy weather all week... and it has done the job completely. It appears to be sufficiently warm and completely breaks the wind. One challenge with any down fleece is you can't get them super wet, so you definitely don't want to be stuck in a situation where this will be your only cover in a steady rain. The four pockets are handy (and warm) and the fabric extensions on the sleeves add warmth and cover those spots that are usually left exposed while wearing gloves. The zip up collar does well at protecting the neck and is not uncomfortable at all.

When going indoors it is a must to remove it because you would overheat otherwise, but the light weight and compressibility of this jacket makes it easy to stuff into a pack or bag. It can be compressed to about the size of a football, but at less weight. Wearing while unzipped does a fair job of releasing the heat.

I like the fit of this jacket... I wear medium and this appears to be true to size. It is a snug fit for my slim frame and does not look like one of those overly puffy jackets. The fabric is a matte finish, rather than the shiny finish in other brands.

While I have been evaluating the warmth of this jacket during a trip to Vancouver, BC, the real test will come next month while in Alaska. I'll update my entry after that.

UPDATE - 1/4/13
I did have a chance to wear it in Alaska in December where it was between 1 and 20 degrees.  I had to have a couple of layers on underneath, and then of course a warm hat.  But it was fine (no wind).  Later, while skiing in Washington in January at 25 degrees, it served as a good insulator beneath my Columbia shell. It has a different zipper system than the shell so it did not zip in, but that was not a big deal.

product_title: Columbia Men's Path To Anywhere Ii Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Warm, comfortable, lots of pockets
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2014
review_body:
Bought the large size... I'm 6' 190lb and jacket fits a little loose which is what I was looking for (fit is perfect if I'm wearing a sweater underneath). Plenty storage for gloves/phone/wallet.

Features
5 exterior pockets (4 pockets are down by your hands, 1 pocket is zippered on the chest)

    Brrrrr, it's cold out there
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2014
review_body:
I bought this jacket because it was on sale one day and my old one like this was falling apart.  Today is the first day I've worn it and it's doing pretty well in low 40's with a 5 degree windchill.  The pockets are fleece lined and there are plenty of them.  It's fairly thin for a big coat and I don't feel like the marshmallow man in it.  I was able to drive well in it as well.

Columbia seems to have a good history of construction from my experience, so I'm hoping this will last a few years at the least.  I still have a Columbia shell from the 8th grade that will not die.  Unfortunately, it's also in neon pink, teal and purple...

reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Quality winter coat
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2014
review_body: I typically wear an XL but ordered this coat in L after trying both on in the store. I am 6'2" and 180lbs, athletic build with long arms and wide shoulders. I would suggest buying a size smaller than you normally would and it will still be plenty big to wear a T-shirt and hoodie underneath. I wore this coat in temperatures ranging from 30 to -6 ( actual temp without wind chill), and I was toasty warm for a few hours of light walking with quite a bit of standing around. Would highly recommend this for anybody who wants a good winter jacket without too much bulk. Also love the detachable hood and lots of nice lined pockets. I orders the Mystery color which is a steel blue and black..looks awesome! For the price you are getting a great looking, quality winter coat!

product_title: Columbia Men's Path To Anywhere Ii Jacket
reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A Disappointing Jacket From Columbia
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2015
review_body:
As previous posters noted, this jacket runs very large to common sizes.  I typically wear a size large but ordered medium for this jacket and it still fits fairly loosely.

As a long time buyer of Columbia, I do not like this jacket.  It does offer layered protection but it is bulky and won't stuff down like I expected for backpacking.  The pockets were lined with a nylon that snagged the skin on my hands and actually hurt in the cold weather.

There is an insulated hood on the jacket (without a place to stow it when not needed) with chin strap but I couldn't figure out how to tighten it around my head and needed a free hand to hold it closed.

If it hadn't cost me so much to return, I would not have kept it.  But looking back I should have because I doubt I will use it much again.

product_title: Columbia Men's Path To Anywhere Ii Jacket
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Basic jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2014
review_body:
Height : 5'7"
Waist: 38
Weight: 175

Bought this to replace my last Columbia jacket (dog chewed through it...long story, don't ask) which was the Antimony III. The Antimony III specs are similar to this jacket, but the PTA-II runs a tad smaller and feels lighter. I generally wear a large, but this coat feels oversized. However, with a layer, such as a thick sweater, it fits better. The Antimony III ran quite large as well and I decided to wear medium. This worked well, but layering was a chore. The 150 grams of synthetic insulation should bode well for NYC winters and water repellant fabric is a well known feature for Columbia's coats and jackets. Pockets are plentiful on the outside of the jacket with a small zipped chest pocket, two handwarmer pockets, and two large storage pockets. There is an interior pocket on the inside of the jacket, but is the only one which is a bit disappointing. The storage pockets, cuffs, and placket over the zipper close with snaps which I prefer to Velcro but some others may not. The hood is large, insulated, and adjustable with integrated lines. It zips off if you prefer the jacket without it. I'm expecting a similar level of performance from this jacket as I did the last. The Antimony III was comfortable with minimal layering down to the 20's for me. I hope that improved capacity for layering with this jacket with surpass those temperatures. New York has been a cold place to live over the past few years.

reviews:

review_title: Nice jacket if you get right fit

review_body:
I bought this jacket like a year ago. I wear most of medium sized jackets but this one fits little bit larger. More specifically, it is little bit longer if you are short, I am 5' 6", 160lb.

Pros:

Cons:

product_title: Columbia Men's Path To Anywhere Ii Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    This coat is great and my son loves it
review_title: This coat is great and my son loves it
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2014
review_body:
This coat is great and my son loves it.  He is too big for a kids extra large ad that leaves only a men's small.  This coat fit him well and there is room to bundle him up and still zip the coat closes.  We had some cold days thus far and he says he is nice and toasty in his Columbia coat.  What he likes is the warmth with out the puffiness.  It's also great because it's water and wind resistant.  I was ok with the price. I had just returned a coat I bought for him at a local store which is a national chain store and took it back after
1 week.  The coat that I purchased for $70.00 was loosing it's stuffing.  So that is why I looked at Columbia.  For 30.00 more I got him a better quality coat that will hopefully last him through two growing seasons.

reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    good materials
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
review_body:
This jacket uses very good materials and has kept me dry. It is a 3 layer design. Similar to gore-tex pro but not the same. It has a slim fit so size up if you are unsure.

I would pick this over a gore tex jacket if you can find a good deal. If they are the same or close enough in size, I'd go with gore-tex.

Overall very good though designed for hiking and mountaineering more than going to the grocery store. This is why there are 2 chest pockets on the outside and no side hand pockets (where your hip belt would go from your pack).

Helmet compatible, but can also be used without a helmet.

review_title: Good jacket with a fitting cut

review_body:
Good jacket with a flattering(fitting) cut. Good for slender folks. I'm 190cm tall(6ft 3") and wearing M and the sleeves are just right past my wrists. Size up if your girth is wider or require longer sleeves.
Went through a storm up a tropical mountain and not getting soaked but perspiration doesn't wick fast though I doubt any jacket will in a 90+% humidity.
The pockets are like bags made of mesh with the openings sewn to the openings of the pocket and you pull the entire jacket through either pockets from inside out and they become a pouch to hold the jacket with a zip enclosure.

product_title: Columbia Men's Tree Grinder Shell Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Daily Durability
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2013
review_body: After way too much time shopping around the internet and comparing features, I chose to order the Columbia "Tree Grinder" jacket over all the other options. I've only had the jacket about a week, but so far, this thing is seriously delivering on every front. Let me tell you some background: I live in one of the top three rainiest cities in the United States. I'm talking over 120+ inches/year. I do not own a car, but commute on my bicycle, everyday. This jacket is 100% WATERPROOF. I took it out of the box, rode down the street, and literally stood in the pouring rain, just to test it out. If any moisture made it through, I would have returned the jacket right away, but my upper half was powder dry. The thick outer fabric is windproof, too. The jacket is loaded with features, like waterproof pockets galore, double zippers in the front, fully adjustable billed hood, adjustable cuffs with extra length at back of hands (which can roll up to create a gutter that diverts water away from hands), ultra-futuristic NASA style reflective inner lining (Omni-Tech)... all kine stuff. I believe the design is geared towards snowboarders, as there is also a powderskirt and buttons to attach to pants. The bottom line is, you absolutely will stay dry in this thing. If I have any gripes, it it is only that breatheability is only so-so with the zippered armpit vents; and because it is a shell jacket, it runs pretty large to accommodate further layering.  But, I am talking about wearing a snow jacket in a tropical rainforest climate, so maybe you will appreciate the extra warmth. It never really dips below 60 degrees here, so I haven't had to wear any extra insulating clothes underneath the jacket. The materials are very nice, construction seems much sturdier than some of the Columbia jackets in the lower price range, and the styling is unique. Again, it does run a bit large, in my opinion, but the extra length just means that more of you is shielded from the elements. All in all, a great coat, and I highly recommend it.

product_title: Columbia Men's Modern Logger Jacket
Columbia Men's Modern Logger Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Awesome
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2012
review_body: light weight(because of the Omni-Heat Shield, not constrictive, solid winter coat. The weather really hasn't dropped into the teens yet but this coat has been comfy and warm on days when it's been in the mid 20's into the 30's. Inside pocket is big enough for anything you really want to carry and the exterior pockets are large as well. The Velcro on the sleeves provide a nice way to tighten up the fit when wearing gloves. Plus, this is just a style of jacket you won't see around much. Overall well worth the cost. I'm 6'4" and the fit is excellent.

product_title: Helly-Hansen Mens LIFALOFT Insulator Pullover
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Better than the Outdoor Research Baja pullover
review_title: Better than the Outdoor Research Baja pullover
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_body: I have one of the Bajas from OR and two of these pullovers from HH and I really like all three of them. They fit on and off easily with a quality side zipper and they keep me warm down to 30 degrees F. It might work in colder but I've never had to try that (thankfully). I prefer the HH pullover because it is not as puffy as the OR Baja and also because it has two zip pockets instead of the OR kangaroo/sweatshirt type hand pocket. The HH also lays nicer on the body. Both fit about what I expect and both have decent hoods, too. The HH hood doesn't have an adjustment point though and this really needs to be upgraded. Now, you have to zip it up the middle all the way for the hood to stay in place and there are times when you want the hood stable and not zipped up all the way so please add an adjuster to the next version, HH! Otherwise, this thing is perfect and basically is the nicest sweatshirt I've ever seen. I have it in black and in orange, by the way. The orange is called 'bright orange' and it is bright but its not a neon orange or anything odd looking like that. Its quite nice really and my go-to piece for basically any cold day activities.  P.S. I bought mine on sale prices better than Amazon and directly from Helly. Hope that helps.

This is my second "puffer" style jacket. This one seems superior in terms of warmth and style. I like that stitching between "puffs" is closer together. I like the collar also comes up high and tight enough that actually helps keep in the warmth and the wind off your neck. The zipper is super smooth and very easy to get the first teeth started without trouble.

reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020
review_body: This Wrangler puffer jacket is not very fluffy, I was assuming it was going to be like a quilted type; which it does look like one, but does not feel like one. Yes it does have some fluff to it so I cannot say it completely flat, still it is not very puffed up either so its alright. Wrangler is a great company so I know the quality in the seams and fabric are there, but they did cheap out in the insulated department. Overall it does keep you Simi warm, the only downfall it has is the inside is not lined; So therefore you have the same material that is on the outside of this jacket on the inside as well, even the pockets have that same "outside fabric" inside them. The medium does fit him pretty well, for reference my husband is 5'11, 160lb with wide shoulders. Still I do recommend as this jacket is very nice.

review_title: Nice warm, light-weight jacket with a style statement
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2019
review_body:
The jacket has a fluffy feel which I liked and its very lightweight.  I have been using it for a while and it has become my “to go” jacket now. I cant say about other sizes but the medium size fits nicely and is as expected.

The zipper is pretty easy to close and runs very smooth. The jacket stays pretty warm and is all right for light cold weather. But it is definitely not the right choice for a temperature approaching the freezing point.

I have washed it once in the machine (because I spilled coffee on it and it was anyways looking a little dirty). I was surprised to see that it retained its texture and the same feel. There was absolutely no damage due to washing (but that doesn’t mean, I am suggesting to wash it every week ;).

Overall, it’s a nice light-weight jacket which I live to wear.

product_title: ATG by Wrangler Men's Range Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I like it
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
review_body:
As soon as I removed this jacket from the packaging and slipped it on I liked it. It has a slightly shiny smooth and soft material inside and out. It slides on without the resistance of the jacket it is replacing which had a cloth interior that would pull rather than slip when putting it on.

This jacket is light weight, not very thick, and feels quite comfortable. I also like the length because I often wear shirts that are not tucked in. This jacket is just long enough to fully cover my shirts.

The side pockets are zippered which is great because they are secure from things possibly falling out. Additionally the pockets are not shallow.

This is a cool weather, not a cold weather, jacket which is perfect for me. We live in an area where the daytime temps rarely drop below 40 degrees. The sleeves have a soft elastic around the wrist which isn't too tight but will keep the wind out. There are drawstrings around the bottom of the jacket which I'm not likely to use but some others might.

The only thing I don't like is the "stand up collar"  which tends to touch my cheeks when the jacket is not fully zipped up. Perhaps the collar will not stand up after some use, or I could put a stitch in it to keep the collar down. I don't think the stand up collar is needed on a jacket of this temperature range.

Being water resistant is also perfect for me as this city does not usually receive hard rain.

I highly recommend this jacket.

product_title: ATG by Wrangler Men's Range Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    WOW! What a Sharp and Functional Jacket!
review_title: WOW! What a Sharp and Functional Jacket!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2019
review_body:
I’m a little out of the loop when it comes to Male fashion these days, but I keep seeing these Hollywood Stars wearing a similar style.

This is an excellent jacket. It’s so lightweight, yet warm and waterproof. Made by Wrangler, it’s well sewn and finished, with smooth gliding heavy-duty zippers, and ample zippered pockets. It has a concealed drawstring around the bottom, I suppose, for keeping the wind out.

It fits my husband, true to size, and is pretty darned good looking. For being as padded as it is, it doesn’t look bulky. It’s low maintenance too! Being 100% Polyester, it’s machine washable in cold water/low tumble dry. You can’t ask for too much more than that! It arrived pleasantly packaged also, complete with its own hanger and a full plastic bag – no creases!

I wouldn’t hesitate to purchase this first-rate garment and am appreciative of the opportunity to receive and review it.

review_title: Fits well but slightly short in the arms. Warm and comfortable.

review_body:
Comfortable quality made jacket, the M runs true to size in the body however just a tad short in the arms. Anyone with broader shoulders or longer sleeve length, this could be an issue. Everything other than the sleeves fit great.

This jacket is really warm while also being lightweight. It's not thin, this jacket is definitely on the fuller, puffy side. Full thicker collar for neck warmth. Strong zipper with a good zipper pull.
The hand warmer pockets are good sized, not lined.
No interior pockets, which is surprising. Not a deal breaker but worth mentioning.
Polyester to repel weather.

My son really likes this jacket. He lives in the city and does a lot of walking; it gets cold here and so far this has been a warm and all the pockets make it a very useful jacket. Looks good, too!

product_title: Columbia Men's Compounder Shell Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great light weight jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2013
review_body:
A well known gear lab tested this jacket and then trashed it in a review.  I didn't believe them and very pleased I did not.  The Compounder is about 19 oz. compared to their best choice the Arcteryx Alpha SV which is 2 oz. less and $300 more!  Later, I saw the Compounder was highly rated by Backpacker magazine.

The breathability is nearly as good as some fabrics that cost much more.  Unfortunately, I am aware of that...

The XXL is true to size and a relaxed fit with long arms leaves plenty of room for winter layering. The Compounder has an easy-to-adjust hood; soft face lining; and internal mesh pockets handy for storing gloves.

While waterproof pocket zippers all run smoothly, the main zip requires wrestling.
The pit zips are very long...

The Compounder maybe a tad heavier than $600 jackets, but the result is that it offers multisport potential: It crosses over into skiing and mountaineering, yet it’s not too heavy for backpacking.

A great product from Columbia.  Never count them out!

review_title: Great Coat, used for CO ski trip so far and general wear
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2013
review_body: Purchased for CO ski trip, needed better jacket.  This fit the bill.  Skied in 15-20deg F with thermal wicking shirt, long-sleeve cotton t-shirt, and medium/light acrylic sweater, this was great, and a little too warm.  Has front and under-arm vents.  Pocket for phone was nice, along with goggle pocket (used for gloves).  Seems durable, no tears from rubbing on trees or branches so far.  Fairly lightweight, warm, breathable, sleeves are nice with stretch cuffs under gloves, also powder skirt seemed to work.  Did not use hood, or try with helmet.  "reflective" shiny stuff inside seems like a joke, it is just paint or ink dots on inside fabric... either way it was warm.

product_title: Columbia Men's Cubique II Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Size is true to Columbia's sizing chart
review_title: Size is true to Columbia's sizing chart
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2013
review_body:
To be sure of the best fit, I purchased a Large & XL from Amazon at the bargain prices of $110 & $89 respectively.  I would have preferred a different color than Black, but it was too good a price to pass up.  It's still September in Southern California, so I won't be able to comment on its utilitarian properties until my ski trip in January, but there are plenty of other reviews on the subject.
Back to the sizing.  I'm 6-0", 207 pounds, 44" chest, 37" waist, and 33" sleeve length.  The Large was definitely the best fit on me.  The shoulders fit fine, and there was still an extra inch or two available in the sleeve length if needed.  I was able to readily swing my arms around without any restriction in my motion.  There's still room for some layering underneath (e.g. silk undershirt and fleece jacket).  Other reviewers commented on how warm this jacket is, so I doubt you'll need too much layering ... but all bets are off if you layer like the Michelin Man.
Until I actually ski in this jacket in cold and wet conditions, my 5 star rating is conditionally based on the 70% discount price I paid.  Otherwise, the sole purpose of this review is to provide readers additional sizing feedback.

reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Light but Warm
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2011
review_body: I needed a lightweight jacket because I get in and out of a car all day. I needed warmth because it gets pretty cold here in the Northeast. I needed both wind and rain protection because I am on the road and can't switch coats. This jacket does it all. I was amazed just how warm this jacket keeps me. You can wear it with just a shirt on underneath and you are good to go when the temp is as low as 35 degrees. Since I have to work in temperatures as low as 20 degrees, just layer a thin garment underneath. I have not had a chance to play golf with it yet, since most people don't play when it's snowing. I am sure it will perform just as well. I have never paid this much for a jacket before. It is worth every penny.

product_title: Fjallraven Keb Jacket - Men's
reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Other reviewer stole my headline from other fjallraven reviews and has exceptional grammar, therefore he's a paid reviewer.
review_title: Other reviewer stole my headline from other fjallraven reviews and has exceptional grammar, therefore he's a paid reviewer.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2016
review_body:
The other reviewer stole some key points about my other fjallraven reviews and this time he even stole my headline. For that reason I believe he is actually a paid reviewer and I will counter his review.

In his review he mentions key features in a positive manner. Those features are true to the product, however, the jacket is not insulated in any way whatsoever. Its basically a durable shirt. Also, the entire back of the jacket is not G-1000 material, which is nothing more than tightly woven polyester by the way, but the parts that are not G-1000 are a thin spandex material that you would see common underwear made of. Its about as thick as underwear too.
The jacket is very well tailored and has nifty designs in places that make it a really good jacket.
But in conclusion, the materials its made out of is just low frequency polyester and a thin layer at that. It is not water resistant at all. I have the entire Keb outfit. Its good for wind protection but in rain it soaks up water like a sandman. This jacket is NOT worth anything more than 180$ in the market compared to other jackets made with the same amount of material.
That being said, if you're willing to pay the price like I did, thats your personal right.

product_title: Fjallraven Keb Jacket - Men's
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    If Chuck Norris were a hiking jacket, he would be this one
review_title: If Chuck Norris were a hiking jacket, he would be this one
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2015
review_body:
Fjallraven makes great outdoor gear, that's all there is to it.  I love this jacket, but a few items to note if you are considering one:

1.  The torso and arms are generous, so it fits more like a "tall" size.  Love it for me, but that may not be good news for you depending on your preference.
2.  This jacket will resist drizzle, but it is not a rain jacket.  The G-1000 material on the hood, shoulders, lower sleeves, and lower torso can be easily treated with Greenland wax and can be highly water resistant; however, the other panels are a much stretchier material.  I treat the G-1000 with wax, then treat the stretchy panels with Nikwax or Cabela's waterproofing spray.  It will do great in anything but a sustained downpour.
3.  The hood is substantial.  This is great news for wind and the elements, but can take a little getting used to.  Depending on how it adjusted, it can be configured to be a limited-vision tunnel that stands well out in front of your face.  Fortunately, it is highly adjustable, including the ingenious use of a flexible wire inside the front of the hood that can be shaped.
4.  The jacket is a little lighter weight than it appears.  It's no warmer than a standard soft-shell, but far more durable and functional.  The jacket has a trim but not slim fit, so room for layering underneath.

I have received so many compliments on this item!  It really stands out in a good way.

product_title: Oakley DWR Elkhorn Jacket
Oakley DWR Elkhorn Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    For Oakley fan
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
review_body:
If you like wearing Oakley gear, you'll like this. I cannot provide too much experiential information on it since it is too warm to wear. This will be a nice hiking jacket for the mountains of AZ in the fall. The blue isn't too bright but is it enough to get noticed on the trail if you want to be seen when hiking in a large group. The thickness is roughly the same as a Polartec 100 level. Though I think this jacket is more dense than that. Four stars - instead of five - due to the length of the sleeves. I like the thumb-hole option but I don't like having the sleeves bunched up so much if I choose not to wear it like that.

I can't say I'd give 4 stars for the posting. It did post "Dry Clean only" but that may have been due to a previous review (do your research). I washed and dryed this jacket as instructed on the tags and all came out fine. Plus, the photos didn't show how the material was textured inside and out for a better idea of what you're buying.

If the red jacket was available, I would purchase on a marked down price. I'm not sure this jacket is worth more than $60.

reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Bad branding but great jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2019
review_body: The quality is surprisingly good for a Chinese product you've never heard of. I totally believe the design came from the UK with all the adjustment straps and inner and outer zippered pockets (even a pen holder). It has just as many features as a $200 Patagonia. Only time will tell if it holds up, but upon first impression, it seems even better made than jackets by Columbia, North Face or Bauer, at least on their lower end. It's not too heavy or insulated, but I wouldn't wear it on a summer hike. The only reason I give it 4 stars is because the zipper is left-handed. I don't know if that has anything to do with it's English design, but I find it a bit cumbersome. Recommended though.

reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2018
review_body: This is as close as you can get to the 1970's mountain parkas. It is long enough to cover your crotch and upper thighs, stout, quite waterproof, rather heavy. For the normal price of 150 it's a good value. When its on sale, it's a screaming deal.

product_title: Mountain Warehouse Glacier II Mens Long Waterproof Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Value and quality.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2021
review_body: This jacket was more than I expected and maybe even a little more than I had hoped. I really needed a rain jacket to use with my down jackets and coats. It needed to fit a little loosely so that I wouldn't have any problems with it crushing the down and losing the insulating value of it. I also wanted something that would breath and not break the bank. A hood was also very important and pockets. This was the best I could find that included ALL of those features. First the pluses: 1, the fit is almost perfect for me and for layering. I really could have gone with a large instead of an extra large, if I only wanted to use it for mild temperatures. 2, The looseness also helps in the breathing category because it doesn't completely trap the air and moisture released from the body inside the jacket until your clothing becomes saturated and starts to rob your body of heat. Yes it says that the fabric is breathable, but even the most expensive "breathable waterproof fabrics"  have this problem. 3, The hood is more than I had hoped for. I knew that it zipped off, which is important and which I like but the adjustment cords are very good too. I was a little concerned when I first put it on and tried to snug it down with the two side cords, and they didn't do much. Then I realized that I hadn't done anything with the cord on the back of the hood. It's a system and you need to use all of them to get it really snugged down. There is also a stiffener in the brim of the hood that keeps the hood out further from your face and stops rain or snow (To a degree. Nothing stops horizontally driven stuff. lol) from getting on my glasses. 4, Pockets. Lots of pockets. Two large pouch/cargo pockets on the outside front with Velcro flaps, Two hand warmer pockets BEHIND those (I'll get to that in a minute.), one chest pocket with a zipper on the wearers top left outside and one chest pocket with Velcro on the top right inside. Now the negatives. 1, It's a lot heavier than I really wanted. Solider, rugged and well made. I was hoping for something that "could be" easily carried in or on a backpack. This is rather bulky and heavy for that. In certain situations I certainly "might" strap this on top of my pack. It is definitely lighter than my mountain parka soft shell (Which cost about 3 to 4 times what this did.), but that is for expected bad weather in more extreme environments. I was looking for those swing season, I never expected THAT to happen situations where I needed something better than the fits in your pocket rain coat. 2, The hand warmer pockets BEHIND the pouch/cargo pockets on the lower front. Here's the problem. The opening into these is only as wide as the pockets are tall. The pouch/cargo pockets will hold quite a bit, but they are not all that deep. My bare hands fit in just fine, and with a pair of light gloves on They will still fit, BUT if you have on anything that has some real insulation, you CAN NOT GET YOUR HANDS INTO THE POCKETS. I understand exactly why the manufacturer did it this way. It is a cost effective way for them to get a lot of pockets onto the jacket without raising the price to high. The pouch/cargo pockets are simply sewn on top of the outside of the coat on only three of the four sides. The top, bottom and inside edges are sewn and the outside edge is left open for a somewhat serviceable hand pocket underneath. Clever and cost effective, however it creates two problems. One, it is hard to get a gloved hand into the pocket and two, if you put anything of any size into the pouch/cargo pocket on top of it, it will not expand to allow use of the pocket under. 3, No pit zips. These are almost mandatory for a coat of this design. Thigh length, waterproof, heavy duty fabric, with two way zipper, Velcro storm flap over the zipper, high, stand up collar and full hood and bungie pull cords on the bottom hem to keep out the elements. It is ment to be battened down to keep out the storm, and that means trapping in the heat and sweat. 4, The zipper is on the left instead of the right side, but then this was obviously designed in Great Britain, and they even drive on the left, so what ya goin' ta do. LOL. Now that my ramble is pretty much done, I want you to know that I love this rain coat, ESPECIALLY for the price I paid for it. I can and will live with all of the negatives I listed and would have easily up my score to FIVE STARS if it had pit zips.

product_title: Mountain Warehouse Glacier II Mens Long Waterproof Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good quality and comfort to wear
review_title: Good quality and comfort to wear
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
review_body:
I was looking for a longer rain coat for every day wear.  It is important that the material will keep the water out but allow body sweat to get through.  I wore it for two weeks now, it has been raining a lot lately.  The material is light and the sweat wasn't trapped, body stay dry.
The jacket is long enough to cover to upper tight.  One thing I really like about this jacket is the pockets.  If you look closer to the pictures vendor provided, you will notice that there small pocket outside and inside for cell phone or wallet or anything for easy access.  the front pockets are large and designed to keep water from getting inside.  It even has a pen holder.  The hood is pretty large, it covers well.  You can pull the elastic band to tight up the hood so it will keep the hood from blow away from strong wind.  I hope the elastic band material will last, only time can tell.
I wish they design it to add a down or thermal liner for winter.  Overall, nice design, great materials, I would recommend this to others who looking for a good quality rain jacket.

product_title: Columbia Men's Trophy Shot Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Best Jacket Ever
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2014
review_body:
This jacket is truly warm, windproof, and waterproof.  It's light weight and soft (flexible) fabric make it much more comfortable than my other camo jackets.

Never thought a non-down jacket could be warm enough, but this jacket is great in windy, sub-zero temps while shoveling snow.  Been there, done that!

It's hard to fault the jacket, but a large tooth zipper would be easier to operate.  Regarding size, my XL fits well, but if you like extra room through the belly, maybe order a size larger.  The wife, who's petite, bought a Small, and she loves it.

Overall, this jacket is a winner and well worth the price.

reviews:

    Is That "Navy" or "Buffalo Check"?
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2016
review_body: The size, fit, and quality are excellent as I've come to expect after the other five Fjallraven shirts I've purchased.  The shirt that arrived however, looks much more to me like Red Buffalo Plaid (aka Lumberjack Shirt, Red/Black Checkered, or Red Plaid, Buffalo Check, Canada Plaid, etc.) shirts I already own, and less like the shirt I wanted after seeing the picture online. With specific lighting and a little imagination, I can begin to see Navy instead of black, and I can imagine that the light red stripes match the apparent red/orange stripes in the Skog pictured.  But the picture and "Navy" label do not much to manage expectations.  If I did not already have nearly identical shirts, I probably would not mind.

    Channel your Flannel
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2016
review_body: This is a terrific shirt.  I am tall (6'0") and skinny (30inch waist) with long arms so a lot of flannel-type shirts look very baggy on me. I got a medium and it has a perfect tailored-yet-casual look, with perfect length on the sleeves. It must be the Scandinavian sizing for those lean Viking types...  The material is a very heavy, yet soft, cotton. Definitely a winter shirt, as warm as any fleece, and I've even taken to wearing it like a light jacket this fall. The construction is impeccable and I expect this shirt will be a favourite for many seasons.

reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The hood has a perfect design, excellent protection of the face
review_title: The hood has a perfect design, excellent protection of the face
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2017
review_body:
The main benefit of a jacket is a hood! The hood has a perfect design, excellent protection of the face. Excellent balance between wind-shelter and breathable properties, especially, when you go with a backpack. The main shortcoming is a weight. For a trip duration about one week it is normal, for more long trip it seems is too big. However benefits outweigh, and I am going to take this jacket in a three-week campaign in Kamchatka. Used greenland wax, but didn't get to a sleet yet therefore water protective properties didn't manage to be checked.
Size XL for 190 cm, 85 kg - precisely in the size.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good with Caveats
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_body: Bought this at an outdoor equipment store.  went straight for a XXL because I have a big chest (45"), and I'm 6'2" in height. It fit well but I'll have to be careful what insulation layers I put underneath. It is well manufactured with some well thought out features. The hood can become huge which no doubt is useful in certain situations. The 2 external pockets are only at chest level but have a large volume. As you would expect, there are decent features/drawcords to tighten things up around the hood, neck, wrists etc. and great ventilation zippers at the arm pit that extends quite a bit down the side of the jacket. The G-1000 fabric is really hard-wearing but require a good amount of waterproofing wax to seal you in. Soon after purchasing I was caught in a light shower and all was good. The first sustained rain I experienced wearing it, and it leaked, mostly around the seams. I have since applied copious amounts of their proprietary wax to all G-1000 sections, doubling up on the seams, to waterproof the jacket. This takes a solid 90 minutes to do and a hair-dryer to evenly distribute the wax and melt it into the fabric. I know from experience with other wax jackets that this will need to be repeated once or possibly twice per year to keep the jacket waterproofed if you use it regularly. That's is the "caveat" in the title. There will be on-going upkeep with this jacket that extends beyond wiping with a damp cloth, or a wash and re-seal with Nikwax products.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Finally a huge jump forward in jacket design for those that actually perspire in them.
review_title: Finally a huge jump forward in jacket design for those that actually perspire in them.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2015
review_body: I worked outdoors as a geologist for a decade in the '80s and my parka was my most important piece of equipment. Since then I hike, mountaineer, bike ride for fun.  I get a new contemporary parka about every ten years. I live in the Pacific Northwest and hike twice a week. I have a two year old top of the line North Face Parka... the Fjallraven is an order of magnitude better for all but a full day of heavy rain. It is some much more breathable than Gore-tex it is not funny. It is so comfortable and quiet, I frequently forget to take it off when I get home. I use it with the Keb pants, which have cargo pockets that compliment the Jacket (no pockets where the pack waist straps go). The brown open weave material is so breathable it is like not having any material holding up evaporation. But hit the blackberry patches and the lighter colored material is impervious to thorns. Pocket layout is outstanding for wearing a pack. To make the Ocher colored material more waterproof you wax it... so you can adjust the "waterproofness". So the range of conditions where this jacket is comfortable is really large.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I really like the quality of all Fjallraven products and this jacket ...
review_title: I really like the quality of all Fjallraven products and this jacket ...
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2018
review_body: I really like the quality of all Fjallraven products and this jacket is built with great quality. The soft stretch material on the chest arms and back will allow for moisture to be wicked away. The chest pockets are huge, which I like. The hood is also very big, but appropriate for its function: it will keep out precipitation and provide full head coverage and protection from wind.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Cool and very practical jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2014
review_body:
The quality is, as promised and usually kept by Fjallraven, superb, down to the smallest seam.
I like the practicality of the two big (really!) front pockets. One has to get used to the absence of side pockets for your hands, but that's a detail… There are a few inner and other small pockets, great for storing and keeping organized your gadgets.
The combination of G1000 and stretch material makes it very comfortable to wear, despite the snug fit (good if you want to keep a slim silhouette when crawling through the bush). The hood is an amazing feature, retaining decent vision while really keeping the elements out.
Overall no regrets whatsoever, the price is not outrageous either, especially as I expect this to last many more years...

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A joy to wear, but limited by choice of fabrics
review_title: A joy to wear, but limited by choice of fabrics
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2014
review_body:
I got the jacket as well as the Keb pants.  They are really excellently crafted, styled, and constructed, and are a joy to wear.  Given their choice of materials however, I will be somewhat challenged to decide when I will wear them.  Being not fully waterproof, not fully wind-proof (the stretch fabric portions), and not lightweight enough to be good for multi-day backpacking and mountaineering, they seem best suited to day hikes in cool conditions where heavy and prolonged rain won't be likely.  I have the wax, but have not yet applied it (don't know how I can get it inside of the big front pockets to the G-1000 fabric there, either).  I may try out the jacket as a ski shell this winter (not when wet snow may be falling however, or in high winds).  It's a shame that such a beautiful design is hindered by less than high-performance fabrics.

As far as size, I'm #190 and 5'11'', with large shoulders and chest.  The large was too tight across the chest to allow me to layer a fleece or light down jacket underneath, so I returned it for an XL, which seems about right.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Fantastic fit and function, outrageous pricing.
review_title: Fantastic fit and function, outrageous pricing.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2014
review_body:
Fjällräven has a longstanding reputation of making great, innovative and typically long lasting products. True to its reputation this is an awesome jacket: it fits snugly, yet offers great range of motion for the user and quality seems to be very good overall. I also like the hood which is HUGE and using a metal cord in the lining it allows you to shape it to fit. Pockets are well placed and the jacket can be opened at the sides for improved warm weather (or activity) ventilation.

The following however must be noted:
-----------------------------------------------

1.) This jacket offers virtually no insulation and must be regarded an outer layer only,
2.) There is more stretch fabric on this jacket than G1000 and protection against the elements is accordingly,
3.) If you are not in better than average shape this jacket will be too tight (I exercise 5 days a week and I am 6ft tall, 180lbs, 6% body fat and size Medium is perfect).
4.) The jacket is 'Made in China'

The last point, 'made in China' is really getting to me; material costs can't be more than 2 dollars (this is just cotton and synthetics) and even factoring in supposedly high R&D costs, if you manufacture this jacket in a low cost country like China, charging this price is just TOO MUCH. Had they made it in Sweden it would still be expensive, but in China? It's nothing short of outrageous.

product_title: Fjallraven Men's Keb Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Excellent jacket for urban winter bicycle commuting
review_title: Excellent jacket for urban winter bicycle commuting
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2015
review_body: This was probably not what it was designed for; but the breathable back and windproof front, amazing huge adjustable windproof hood, long sleeves, 2-way side zip vents and 2-way front zip ventilation options, and big chest pockets all add up to a fine winter bicycle commuters jacket. Get it a size larger than usual so you will have room to layer under it, it runs small. Not waterproof but will stop wet snow and light showers, and unless your commute is very long or you are riding in a deluge you will be OK for most commuting. I love it for this purpose and use it all the time. I can't comment on other uses, but the lack of windproof-ness in back would make me hesitant to use it in the backcountry unless I had something else to wear over it. And it is pretty heavy and heavy duty, I would not want to carry it in my backpack very often but the durability is a plus for urban use. I have not found anything I like better as my outer shell for cold winter bicycle commuting.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great Jacket - however - arrived ripped
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2014
review_body:
This is a fabulous jacket, however, it arrived damaged. The inside liner of the jacket had a 3-corner tear on the right arm.  The tear is all the way through the material, leaving a sizeable hole in the sleeve. The material around the tear is fraying and most likely will be difficult to fix. It does not appear that the tear was caused by inadequate packing, as it is on the inside liner and the outside shell/jacket is not torn.

The jacket itself is true to size and fit well.  The inside liner is shiny (looks similar to aluminum foil) so beware if you think the "flannel liner" is truly "flannel."  The jacket is VERY warm.  The liner looks great zipped into the jacket, as well as by itself.

The only reason I did not rate the jacket 5 stars is because it arrived damaged.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great shell; liner could be better.
review_title: Great shell; liner could be better.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2014
review_body:
I have been in need of a new jacket and liked the looks features and price.  The shell is perfect and on its own deserves five stars. The material has a nice feel, the pit vents have mesh panels in them, so they only open about three inches, but i like them. The hood is adjustable and works great in the rain. The Five external pockets, three with zippers and two with just velcro flaps, and the three internal pockets, one zipper chest pocket, one media player pocket, and a large google pouch that i stash my hat in.
From other reviews I new the liner might be an issue. This jacket would get five stars if it had the classic Columbia fleece liner. The liner is lumberjack on the outside and disco on the inside. Yes it looks like a flannel shirt, put has more of a wool feel to the material. The heat reflective interior is shiney and makes it very warm, and i would probably substitute a plain fleece jacket underneath until Minnesota hits 0 degrees ferenheit. The liner fits a bit tight in the in the shoulders and arms, i would not be able to wear a sweeter with it.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good Jacket Overall
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2014
review_body:
I normally don't write reviews.  However, there is a lot of misleading info in the comments that might make deciding on a purchase difficult.

1) This jacket DOES have two zippers.  The inner set of zippers is used to "zip in" the liner.  If the liner is taken out the second zipper set is usable.  You can also un-zip the liner but keep it in the jacket.  This will give you the liner zipper, and the double jacket zipper (3 in all).  It's pretty obvious that the reason it is designed like this is to avoid putting a total of three zippers into the outer shell.  Navy issue NWU parkas have this exact same design, I'm pretty sure it;s not a flaw.

2) The inner liner collar does "pop out."  However, this can easily be fixed by removing the collar, washing it as instructed, pressing the collar down, and tucking it into the shell after reinstalling it.  After doing this the liner should not prevent the jacket from being zipped all the way up.

3) Sizing is difficult, but you can always return.  I suggest getting the two sizes closest to you and returning the one you don't like.

4) The liner does make the jacket a bit bulky, but it is extremely warm.

5) The liner is not a shirt.  It is an actual zip up liner that looks like a shirt.  Whether or not you like this is up to preference.

The reason this doesn't get five stars is because:
a) I just bought it,
b) While the liner zipper is reversible, the inner shell zipper is not.  This makes it harder to hid the left inner zipper after zipping in the liner (this would make more sense if you actually had the jacket in front of you)
c) The hood can't be tucked into the collar of the shell.

Overall, it's a good jacket and it looks a bit more fashionable than other cold weather jackets (in my opinion).  However, mileage may vary.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I survived the Polar Vortex
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2014
review_body: I bought the Back to Hells Mountain jacket this past fall as I was preparing for another brutal Chicago winter. I had no idea how harsh winter was going be, but this jacket made it through like a champ! In addition to the day-to-day comings and goings in Chicago, I also took this with me exploring in northern Wisconsin (snowshoeing, ice caves, frozen waterfalls, etc.). This jacket offers excellent warmth without the bulk, and has everything you need to handle the outdoors. I've only used the lining separate from the jacket a handful of times, but it's a great feature to have when you want it. I have nothing but good things to say about this one.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great jacket without the bulk!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2014
review_body:
My previous Columbia jacket (Ballistic Parka shell / liner combo) is now over 15 years old and I'm sending it in for warranty repair just because the pull tab on the shell's zipper finally gave out. When temperatures were below zero for severaI weeks, not being able to zip my shell up wasn't very fun! I purchased the Back To Hells Mountain jacket so I would have a jacket while I sent my Ballistic Parka in for repair.

The Back To Hells Mountain jacket is very nice. It's not nearly as bulky as my old Ballistic Parka and is also weighs a bit less. I did find that the liner from my old jacket would NOT work with this new shell.  One side zipped in fine, but the other side, the teeth do not line up properly.  The Omni-Heat definitely works, maybe a little too well sometimes. I've found myself taking the jacket off if I'm going inside somewhere for more than 20-30 minutes or so.  The shell does an awesome job at cutting the wind and rain.  The liner leaves a bit to be desired though. I'm not a fan of the plaid design, but what really bugs me is that the zippers to zip the liner into the shell don't continue all the way up the collar of the liner. So when the liner is zipped into the shell, the collar sticks up and pokes you in the face. In the photos on the product page, the collar is tucked down. I've tried doing this, and within a few minutes of moving around or walking, they pop right back out. I've read another review where the user changed out the included liner with a Zephyr Ridge liner, which looks like the zippers go all the way up the collar on. I may look into doing this down the road, but it will make the overall price of the jacket quite a bit more.

Overall, this is a great jacket for the price with only a few minor annoyances (to me anyway).  I remember paying nearly $300 for my Ballistic Parka over 15 years ago, but considering how long it lasted I think it was a pretty good deal. Hoping this one will last another 15 years!

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Back To Hells Mountain Interchange Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Warm, Comfortable, and Functional
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2015
review_body:
This is my second winter jacket from Columbia and it's far superior to whatever model I had before (donated it already, so I'm not sure which one it was).

Pros:
-Proper fit.
-A good assortment of pockets located in the places I like them.  I use the front pocket with the vertical zipper all the time for my cell phone.  Jacket also has a large pouch-type pocket on the inside for glove storage, which was a requirement for me.
-Quality zippers that are fairly easy to use even with gloves on.
-Armpit ventilation for the outer shell.
-Comfortable outer shell and comfortable liner.
-The plaid liner is very comfortable.  The reflective "disco" inside lining is very effective at retaining your body heat; I can usually only wear the liner for brief periods.
-Hood is comfortable and useful.

Cons:
-Plaid liner jacket doesn't have standard side pockets.  Wasn't a deal breaker for me.
-This jacket model appears to be discontinued and therefore has limited availability and correspondingly high prices now.

I highly recommend this jacket if you can still find it at a reasonable price (less than $150), but if not, try to find the updated version from Columbia that is the most similar.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Key Three II Softshell Jacket
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Jacket With No Function
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2015
review_body:
This jacket serves no purpose. It is too light for walking around, and not styled right for heavy activity.

Despite being an Omni Heat jacket, it provides no resistance to cooler weather - and you can forget about sub freezing temps, may as well wear a poncho. The problem with the jacket is that is has no thermal break. Yes, it has Omni Heat, which is normally functional. However, because the jacket is so thin, anything cold touching the OUTSIDE of the jacket is immediately transferred to the INSIDE of the jacket.

So if you have snow on your jacket, the cold from the snow travels by conduction to the inside of the jacket and to your skin. Omni Hear works by holding in heat from convection, but does nothing for cold transferred by conduction. That cold will come from cold snow, cold rain, cold wind, cold banisters, cold shovels, cold doors, and pretty much anything with which you will have purposeful or casual contact.

I can confirm the jacket is wind proof and water resistant, and breathable - but unless you're going to use this as a car coat, you will be disappointed. I bought mine during a Flash Sale, and paid significantly less than the Amazon listed price, but I still think I paid too much.

You will be cold in this jacket in any type of winter weather. I understand it may be more suited to fall. But if it's a fall jacket then why is there Omni Heat in the shell? If it is meant to be a shell under which you wear warmer clothing there are more functional and less expensive options. If you want to wear it to snow board or as a ski shell, you'll sweat. May work to toss a football around in 40 degree weather, but that is about it.

Upgrading the jacket with a light layer of Thinsulate between the outer shell and Omni Heat fabric would make this a great jacket.

But if you want to walk down to the local cafe and just look good, for that it is perfect. You'll be cold while walking, but you'll look good.

product_title: Columbia Men's Heat Elite Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Cool Jacket, but not perfect
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2012
review_body:
Bought this jacket and am pretty happy with it.  It keeps me as warm as jackets that are much bulkier.  Granted I have only worn it in 25-40 degree temps, so you may have to layer more for colder temps. I'm 6'5" and the XL fits pretty well.  It's just a little short in front, but sleeves are a good length.  The Omni Heat material lining feels pretty soft.  It felt a little scratchy at first on the sleeves but I don't notice it as much since I've worn it more.

Style-wise I like the way it looks.  I wouldn't call it form fitting but it does have a good fit.  The collar doesn't go down well but I like how it looks up anyway.

review_body: My husband is a pretty standard xl - he's 6' tall, 175, not big or bulky, but has always worn an xl because his arms are long and it fits better. This is one awkward jacket. The xl is huge - the seams on the shoulders hang  far off the shoulders and the jacket is enormous in the body, but the large is painful to wear because of the seams under the arms. The large mostly fit, but the seams were so hard and awkwardly placed. He really wanted to love this jacket because it's lightweight yet very warm, but it just didn't work. After returning these, we even found them in a store and tried on other xl and l to make sure he didn't get a one off.

product_title: Columbia Men's Heat Elite Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A little bit thicker than standard fleece jackets
review_title: A little bit thicker than standard fleece jackets
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2012
review_body: I tried this on at a store and I decided to buy it on Amazon because it was the same price and I own an Amazon rewards cc. The product came in a box and it was well packaged. I tried it on and it felt a little stiff in the arm and chest area. I'm 5'9 178lbs and I wear a medium in my other omniheat Columbia jacket but this one felt a little tighter. I'm assuming it felt tighter because of the additional material on the jacket that makes it a little wind resistant. The jacket feels like its made of good quality materials and it felt very warm in seconds. However my problem is the size. I recommend that you go one size up unless you are skinny.

product_title: Columbia Men's Heat Elite Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Fits well...not bulky..great "layering" coat..washes like a dream!
review_title: Fits well...not bulky..great "layering" coat..washes like a dream!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2015
review_body: Polar fleece definitely a light blue ...was thinking it would have more of a grey/greenish tinge ...hard to tell with my monitor...that said..the "silver lining" was a big hit for my son....not meant to be waterproof...need a shell for that...and like the nylon darker blue material...helps cut down on wind.. But again...not a coat for super cold weather....perfect for 30 degrees and up...good layering coat for under a shell for really cold days as it's not too bulky...Washes like a dream. Not too "dressy" for my son...can go from the LaCrosse field to dinner out!

    Very nice jacket - Not suitable for winter !
review_title: Very nice jacket - Not suitable for winter !
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2013
review_body: Excellent 3-seasons jacket. Wind blocking very effective. Light. Fits very well. Warm and comfy for late autumn and early spring. Not for winter though ; below -10C you gotta move to keep you warm. Excellent breathability. I use it for bike riding on cold fall and spring evenings and I was pleasantly surprised by its performance since I previously thought it could be too warm for aerobic exercise. Reminds me of the North Face Denali, in a more bulky version. Very pleased with it so far.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Zephyr Ridge Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Awesome jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2014
review_body: I got this jacket to wear on its own and also to zip inside my other Columbia jacket. It fits perfect inside my other coat and is very warm. I'm 6' 7" and about 260lbs. I got the XXl and it fits very well, it's a tad short but I'm also a tad tall. The Omni heat technology is great, you can actually feel the difference between this and a normal coat. I live in upstate NY and it has been in the single digits for about a month and this coat combined with my other coat keeps me pretty warm. It is very sharp looking and is built well. I have used Columbia products for years and they all stand up well, the zippers, the material, etc. I actually have a coat I purchased in 1994 and it still is in great shape. I would recommend this jacket to everyone, and right now it's just over 100$ and for a good jacket that is unbeatable.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Zephyr Ridge Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    An Amazing Jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2015
review_body:
AWESOME JACKET
I didn't buy mine from Amazon, I have bad mine for over a year now, I wear it for wind proof, for cool and cold days, by cold I mean down to 25 degree.
The Omi Heat is awesome, it keeps the warmth where it should be, This Jacket is 100% windproof, I tested it with a compressor at work, at 120psi the wind did not go through the jacket,
I have the Abyss blue jacket, I wear it almost every day, has ample room in the pockets and the collar is high enough to cover your neck, it is nice with light rain, but not with a down poor. This Jacket is by far my go to jacket for almost any weather condition, with adjustable Velcro on the sleeves, the wrist cuff to seal out wind, and the underarm zippers if it gets to hot, I love this jacket

reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    not so bad but can be used
review_title: not so bad but can be used
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2013
review_body:
pros: it's light and easy to hold/wear.
cons: it is not keeping as warm as I have expected. at about +5C degree  it was on the limits. I think it is crazy to expect from this jacket to  keep you warm under 0 C degrees.
And its zipper is not in the usual side. when you want to zip this jacket, you should pull zipper with your right hand and hold the jacket with your left hand (in opposite of all other jackets). or if you wear the jacket when the shiny omni-tech side is at the outside, then the zipper is normal.

    Husband loved it...so do I!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2014
review_body: I didn't know what size to get for my husband 6'4 and about 230lbs.  I decided on the XL just because I was thinking sweaters would need to fit underneath.  It is really lightweight, it feels slightly heavier than a fleece.  It fits him great and keeps him really warm during these crazy cold Chicago winters.  He even says that it almost keeps him too warm while he is on the train (I explained that is what the armpit zippers are for!). Another thing I like about the coat is the deep pockets, so gloves wont be popping out of his pockets.  Really glad I got it for him for Christmas.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Zephyr Ridge Jacket
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Stylish and warm but has some flaws...
review_title: Stylish and warm but has some flaws...
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2012
review_body:
Needed a midweight wind breaker and saw this jacket at a local sporting goods store. The $190 MSRP wasn't cutting it but Amazon listed it for $115! The jacket is well made using quality materials. It's warm and keeps out the wind. The cuffs have an elastic inner sleeve to help seal off your wrists from drafts drawstrings at the waist.

The outer shell is constructed of two types of polyester; one is smooth and the other is fleece which, unfortunately, acts as a lint magnet.

The lining is also polyester but manufactured to look like a silvery mesh. I believe it's designed to reflect/retain body heat. It seems to serve this purpose but has one drawback; friction. If you're wearing a long sleeve shirt or sweater that isn't made from a very smooth fabric, your shirt sleeves will bind inside the Zephyr's sleeves when you put it on. Basically you have to grab your sleeves with your hand as you slide your arms into the jacket. Other than that, the jacket is stylish and comfortable.

product_title: Columbia Men's Summit Rush Full Zip Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Warm, comfy, wonderful
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2014
review_body:
Living in the northern northeast US, and being outdoorsy, I have an vast assortment of fleece and fleece-like garments from lots of vendors. I generally shy away from Columbia, as they don't really innovate anymore, they just copy what everyone else is doing, but this was a "deal" and I was just saying "I need a new full-zip fleece". There's nothing wrong with it. It has been very warm as a mid-layer during a couple near-zero shoveling excursions this past week, and doesn't overheat me once inside and it is the top-layer. I haven't worn it in the Spring/Fall yet, but I have no reason to believe it won't work well then either.

It's as good of a full-zip lightweight fleece as you're going to find.

Oh, and there are pockets! They're not horribly useful, but to stash keys, chapstick, or other small items, they're perfect.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Evergreen Shell Jacket
Columbia Sportswear Men's Evergreen Shell Jacket
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great Performing Shell - Poor Performing Interchange (Columbia's claim to fame)
review_title: Great Performing Shell - Poor Performing Interchange (Columbia's claim to fame)
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2015
review_body:
I purchased this jacket while on a ski trip. It performed great as a shell but I bought it with the hopes of "interchanging" with other gear.

It does have the interchange snaps in the sleeves and collar, and the extra inner zipper. On returning from my trip I ordered a Columbia Go To Jacket, which is also interchange compatible. However the zipper length is too short to reach the top of the Evergreen's collar (see picture). I called the customer support line and they first stated the Evergreen isn't interchange compatible. After getting them to look at this web page they talked with their manager and recanted their original statement, but they still couldn't give me a list of liner jackets that are known to work. Nor could they provide any indication why the zipper is too short... is the Evergreen Shell too long in the zipper, or the Go To jacket too short. So "interchange compatible" doesn't appear to be a claim that Columbia is willing to stand by.

It is a shame, Columbia looks like a lot of bang for the buck. But I'll stick with other brands if this is the best Columbia can do with their product and customer service.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Evergreen Shell Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Awesome Jacket by Columbia
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2013
review_body:
First of all, my last Columbia © brand jacket kept me dry in the harshest of conditions, at sea and on mountain for 23 years. Unfortunately in it's 24th year it failed to keep me dry in a torrential downpour so I purchased this jacket as shown here as it's replacement.

I need a jacket that offers some insulation but keeps me from overheating when I'm at work (Outdoors).
The jacket is very light and does not restrict my movements at all.
There are zippers to open vents under the arms.
There is an inner and outer front zipper for severe weather.
It is designed to allow layers underneath.
The jacket waist has an inner snow guard, a band that can be tightened around your waist to keep snow (or cold) from going up and under the jacket.
Sleeves can be tightened with Velcro straps around wrists.
When hood is on and jacket zipped up completely it is snug around the neck and warm.
Highly visible color pattern is attractive and functional for being seen. (good for my job)

I've gotten plenty of compliments from co workers and friends whom have threatened to steal it from me jokingly. The price here at $120 can't be beat.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Evergreen Shell Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The shell itself is fine
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2013
review_body:
However- I thought the Interchange system would allow it to work with my Columbia Ballistic II fleece. It does not. The fleece will not zip into the shell. I finally went to a local store that sells a lot of Columbia products and found a fleece for $55 that would work perfectly. The penny pincher in me told me to put it back and just wear one of my existing fleece jackets underneath without worrying about the zip in feature. So- I saved the $$ and walked away from it.

The shell is good- it sheds rain like a champ and is pretty wind proof. The pit zips help regulate the temperature. I can see no actual benefit to the foil-like material on the inside that is supposed to trap heat.
The takeaway- a good shell- but Interchange does not necessarily mean what it says. Buy with caution if you are mixing and matching.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Mighty Light Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Less expensive than North Face, Omni-Heat technology seems to be better than Thermoball
review_title: Less expensive than North Face, Omni-Heat technology seems to be better than Thermoball
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2016
review_body:
The Omni-Heat NASA space blanket technology seems to work a lot better than North Face's Thermoball/Primaloft insulation. The Mighty Light is also less expensive than North Face, which I think is just more expensive because of the brand name. I normally wear Medium, and decided to try the Mighty Light/Lite in Small. The shoulder/chest fits fine (I'm 6'2" 155 lb) and the length is actually better than North Face. The sleeves are a tad short but the overall torso fit is much slimmer and neater than North Face's ultra relaxed fit.

I can wear just this Mighty Lite in 40F, and my torso and arms would be warm while everything else not covered would be very cold. It also works extremely well as a liner for a soft shell jacket.

The stitching isn't exactly the best. It is already starting to unravel near the main zipper

Overall: 4/5 stars, would benefit from better quality stitching
