product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Mighty Light Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Super thin, EXTREMELY WARM
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2015
review_body: As other reviewers mentioned, I laughed a little when I received my jacket in the mail. It's so light weight and thin that the mail courier was able to roll up the parcel and jam it into my small NYC mailbox. Upon first sight and feel, this jacket appears to be a spring or autumn jacket...not worthy to wear in winter weather. Well, I put it to the extreme test yesterday. It was an absurdly cold night (7 degrees, felt like -10 here in NYC with 30mph wind gusts). I wore this light jacket with a sweater and you know what? I WAS WARM! It retains your body heat just enough to keep you warm without overheating you or leaving you with frostbite. Kudos to Columbia for making such a great jacket! My only disappointment is that I wish I knew they came in tall sizes. I'm 6'5" and thin, and bought the large size. While it fits, I think I'd have been best suited for a tall medium. I'm still completely satisfied!!

review_body: I love this jacket. The name speaks for itself: Mighty Light. This jacket is not heavy, however, it really keeps you warm. I've used it for a couple weeks now here in the winter of the northern Midwest and am very impressed. I bought this jacket to wear in the windy conditions anywhere from upper 40s to around freezing. This jacket does not disappoint. Also, if you are not spending a lot of time outside, or if you are staying active outside, this jacket will surely keep you warm enough even down into the mid 20s. This is definitely not a winter jacket, though so keep that in mind.

reviews:

    Lightweight, breathable, and works well
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2019

product_title: Red Ledge Men's Free Rein Parka
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Packed full of features
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2019
review_body:
This is the nicest rain coat I have ever owned.  I'm used to the heavy ones that do not breathe at all.  I was surprised at how well made this Red Ledge rain jacket is.  The rain jacket is a good material thickness for the cooler rainy days, but I also don't think it is too hot when it gets muggy out during the rain.  This jacket has pit zippers which open up a huge area to let you get some fresh air in and the hot air out.

I find these a must now that I've worn a rain jacket with venting areas.  This just makes you so much more comfortable.  I was also able to keep these completely open during the rain and I never got wet.

I also really like the hood on this rain jacket.  Most rain jackets have a hood but it is always in your face and if you turn your head it gets in the way.  The hood has a shock cord running through it that can be tightened, above your ears where a baseball cap is worn, and it keeps the hood in place.  This is great and I found it to be very comfortable.

I am 5'10" and 154 lbs. I read a review that said the rain jacket runs a little small so I ordered a large which is a size up from my normal jackets.  I found this to be just about perfect.  The back is longer than the front of this jacket, which I like for using on a bicycle and the sleeves were just about an inch or two long which is great for reaching for the handlebars on the bike.  I would recommend one size up from your normal size as it also allows you to put another layer on underneath if you need to in colder weather.

review_title: ... and this tops the list over other expensive brands like Marmot and North Face
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2016
review_body:
I've been through several rain jacket over the years and this tops the list over other expensive brands like Marmot and North Face.
Pros:
- I like rain jackets more slim fit and this fits perfect (I got a large, I am 6' 2" and 160 lbs)
- pit zips are very large for more breathing
- sleeves are perfect length (6' 4" wingspan)
- the small bill on the hood perfectly protects your face
- thick enough so it won't rip with everyday use on other objects but thin enough so you don't overheat

I actually have no cons for this jacket as i love everything about it. Hope this helps

review_body: I really like the sturdiness of this jacket. I've worn it out a couple times now and was very glad to have it. It's well ventilated and the vent zippers are tough and placed where they are very easy to use. As some of you may know, the weather in the Pacific Northwest can change quickly, so when the rain and wind kick in, this jacket lets you really batten down hatches and offers fantastic protection from the elements. NOTE: I ordered the orange, this is a really bright international orange much brighter than the product picture on Amazon.  Also, this jacket fits slim. I usually wear XL shirts and jackets and originally ordered this jacket as a XL.  While I could try on the garment there was no room to add any thermal layering thicker than a tee shirt. I reordered as a XXL and this fits much better with plenty of room to add a base layer and a fleece. The larger size also gives you much better freedom of movement.

review_title: Love the arm pit zips; nice & cool but tuff

review_body: Purchased for So. Cal. hiking once El Nino arrives. Love the arm pit zips. Those along with the zips that go way up on the sides provides great inside air flow venting. Seems to stay cool, too. I like cool. It's nice and light be very tough. The color is a bit much, but that color was a great sale price, so it's worth it to have such a great deal on such a quality rain coat. Very happy.

product_title: Red Ledge Men's Free Rein Parka
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Best value in hard shells
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018
review_body: This is the second Free Rein I've bought because I like this jacket so much. The first one kept me dry for 6+ years before the inner waterproof membrane started to deteriorate around the neck area and the zipper jammed due to corrosion. It will probably last longer for most people since I flat out abuse my equipment and expose it to saltwater almost every day.  You should be aware that this jacket is not breathable. At all. If you want air you open the vents. It's also shockingly waterproof. I have worn it in the pouring rain and pounding surf for hours and was still dry and that's why I love it.

product_title: Red Ledge Men's Free Rein Parka
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A Great Rain Jacket For the Price
review_title: A Great Rain Jacket For the Price
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2019
review_body: This is a really nice jacket, I got the green color and love it. it looks really nice, very modern color LOL...in the woods who cares about  it's color ya know? anyway, I take the bus and I don't just use it for backpacking, I use ot on rainy days too when I have to go someplace and wait on the bus. I stay nice and dry, it doesn't make you sweat like you're wearing a trash bag or something (looks a hell of a lot nicer than wearing a trash bag too just sayin) the hood is adjustable too so it's not hanging down in your face and field of vision, there's zips in the pits to veltilate it, the pockets too are made of mesh so if you don't carry anything (I'd be careful about that, don't carry anything in your pockets with sharp corners in it you don't need to anyway, that's why you have a backpack but your phone is good in there, easy to get to, safe in side  and dry)  but anyway, those pocket sif you don't carry stuff in them open the jippers and you've got even better ventilation. the length of it it comes down to my crotch, I'm 5' 10" weigh 180 and I got the large witch  fits good, not tight not baggy. Wish I would've gotten matching rain pants not only for the color but because these are good quality rain jackets, but I got a separate rain pants, also Red Ledge but sort of bronze/brown color anyway, I stay pretty dry,  I've never hiked yet in pouring rain that lasts all day with this jacket yet, but I'm pretty sure anybody's rain jacket and rain pants, if you're in the rain hiking all day longyou're goig to to be wet, from either rain or soaked from sweat because it's so hard hiking up and down mountains with a pack on, you're going to sweat like a hog in any rain jacket in the summer.

product_title: Red Ledge Men's Free Rein Parka
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good thing for the price
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2017
review_body:
Despite the fact that it is a raincoat I bought it as outer layer for skiing and it works well. It gives very good def from wind and the material looks like polyurethane - absolutely waterproof. The size of the pockets with long zippers is very comfortable. The straps on sleeves are good, but sometimes hard to handle with wearing gloves. It is not breathable and since I didn't use vent zips it always was wet inside, when I undressed after skiing. It was not a problem for me, because I dressed jacket over fleece layer, but there are special vent zippers on sides and you can open pocket zippers to vent too. So if you don't afraid of cold you will be dry :) I prefer warm. The back is longer and this is good for them, who wear pants, with bibs it doesn't matter much.
Two things I miss. 1 - small pocket on chest or sleeve for ski pass and 2 - possibility to close and open zipper two ways - from top and from bottom.
My son wear NF Resolve Jacket and his is looking expensive and costs a little bit much than mine, but I still prefer my Green "Red Ledge", because it more comfortable.
I am 6'4" height and 100kg, XL fits me perfect.

reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Shocked at well it works
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2019
review_body: I ironically bought this as a disposable rain jacket-I bike daily here in New York to/from work 18 miles round trip). When the temperature started dropping into the 40s I thought I'd give this a try as a cold-weather garment. I wore it one day when it was 45 wearing only this jacket and a t-shirt. It was fantastic. I couldn't believe it. This morning when I left the house I thought I'd add another layer-a fleece vest. So in 28 degree weather I wore a long-sleeve generic tee, a fleece vest, and this jacket up top. I was perfectly warm! This thing traps heat like nobody's business. I can't tell you how surprising this has been. I love biking in cold weather wearing a minimum of gear. It's fantastic. Highly recommended. Will buy more as a backup-I've found my new winter biking jacket.

reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Not warm enough
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2022
review_body:
I wish this jacket was warmer.  I’ve had it now for one season.  When it arrived I was on the fence about whether it would be warm enough for winter (Central Massachusetts).  I ended up keeping it, but it is not warm enough and I ended up staying with my old worn out north face jacket instead.

I bought this because I wanted a winter coat that wasn’t insulated with goose down (it’s cruel).  My old north face was also insulated with synthetic materials and was plenty warm enough.

It’s made well and it’s comfortable and it looks good.  Pockets are comfortable for your hands.  It’s roomy enough to wear over fleece pullover.  Materials are nice.  Just wish it was warmer.

Note that they put the zipper flap only on the inside only.  Not a huge deal, but if you wanted to use this in active snow storm like while skiing, nothing is stopping the snow from crusting up the zipper.

It looks nice and has (what seems to be) a durable outside fabric. I guess I must be getting overly sensitive to the cold. I ordered two other parkas before this one and each seemed to provide the same amount of warmth.

The first was an $80 parka from Walmart with polyester lining and the second was a down-filled $180 parka from L.L. Bean. I still have a ten-year-old Helly-Hansen ski parka that is shorter and just as warm as this one. The zipper on it was cheap plastic, otherwise, the quality was excellent.

I spent $300 for this parka and I'm not sure that I see a real difference in warmth between the three even though there is a great difference in price.

product_title: Columbia Men's Grade Max Softshell Jacket
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Mixed Feelings...You Decide
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2012
review_body:
First off, I want to note that I bought mine at a Columbia Outlet and it's identical to this one except mine shows "Columbia Titanium" on the logo and this one lacks the "Titanium" designation - they are otherwise identical in construction, materials, features, etc per the description and picture, so I assume it's the same jacket & Columbia at some point decided to make it a part of their Titanium line.

That said, I have mixed feelings about this piece.  First off the positives: the biggest draw is that it looks really nice.  The wooly outer finish makes it look a bit classier than a standard softshell or fleece.  The stretchy sleeve accents and cuffs, however, give it a sportier technical looking edge.  It really rides the fence between sweater and jacket, with the look of a pseudo-cardigan but the sturdier fabric & weight of a jacket.  In any case, it's sharp and handsome.  Second, the fit is accurate with the XL fitting me just like I would expect.  It's not an athletic fit, but not overly baggy either.  A clean design with sleeves that are amply long for this long-armed guy.

Now the negatives:  first, the Omni Heat feature doesn't seem that noticeable.  I wore this outside playing with the kids on a damp overcast day in the low 40s with a long sleeve tee underneath, and was still a bit chilly.  In particular the jacket isn't especially wind-resistant, with occasional light breezes cutting through it a little.  I hoped that with the "Omni Heat" technology it would be toasty in what I consider moderately cool temps, but I was still a bit chilly.  Second, you HAVE to wear this zipped up unless you want to take a major beat down from your friends for the disco shiny silver lining.  Seriously, I think Columbia will go farther with this Omni Heat thing if they can tone down the glitz.  Lastly, this jacket lacks much in the way of technical features.  No extra pockets beyond the two hand pockets, surprising since Columbia is usually great about giving an extra pocket on the chest or sleeve.  There's also no drawstring to tighten the waist, so cold air can find its way in around the midsection.

All in all, I think this jacket works really well for casual use like a sweater.  Is is less effective, however, as a cold weather jacket.
Within that context, it's a good casual wear value at a lower price point (I snagged it for $32!) that you'd expect for a nice sweater.  But if I were spending closer to a hundred bucks or more on a jacket to keep me warm, this one wouldn't make the cut.

reviews:

reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Such a functional jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2012
review_body:
This is my favorite jacket for daily use.  I live in Denver, and this jacket is warm enough for very chilly temperatures, as long as you are somewhat active.  I really do think the "solar blanket fabric" on the inside does reflect heat back into your body.  On occasion, even in below freezing temperatures, if I even jog, I feel my arms and exposed skin start to sweat.

Lightweight, warm, comfortable, fashionable, this coat has it all!

product_title: Columbia Men's Grade Max Softshell Jacket
reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Not very warm, not very wind resistant, but very nice looking.
review_title: Not very warm, not very wind resistant, but very nice looking.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2012
review_body:
This jacket with Omni-Heat technology is not a warm jacket by any stretch of the imagination. I wore this jacket outside in 30 degree/light wind and it provided less warmth than a common fleece hoodie. I would not recommend this jacket if you need something that keeps you warm even though it sports this shiny heat technology.

I was't shocked to find out that it was not warm but I was surprised that it didn't even block light wind. I have cheap lightweight jackets that do a much better job in this category as well. I don't recommend this jacket if you need a wind breaking jacket.

But it really is a sharp looking jacket. Everyone that has seen me in this jacket has commented on how nice it looks. I do recommend this if you are looking for a fashionable sporty type jacket.

I cannot comment on how dry it stays but it looks like it might be OK in that category.

product_title: Columbia Men's Grade Max Softshell Jacket

reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
review_body: ok

product_title: Columbia Men's Grade Max Softshell Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    This jacket is so sick
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2013
review_body:
Completely waterproof despite its sweater-like piece predominantly covering the jacket.  I have had it over a year now and what I like most about it is the omni-heat.  I seriously can take this out on a windy, 35-degree day with a t-shirt underneath and stay warm.  Also, you can also wear this jacket in a business casual environment, which is really nice if you are in outside sales or an office environment.

A large can tend to be a pretty snug fit, so if you plan on adding layers underneath, or you are over 6' tall, get a size up.

product_title: Columbia Men's Grade Max Softshell Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great Jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2013
review_body:
I seldom leave a review of a product (I know, I'm one of those terrible people that will only say something if it's a bad product), but this one deserves it.

This jacket is probably the best jacket I've ever owned.  It's warm, but not overly warm, and blocks the wind just fine.  Yes, if you leave your jacket unzipped, wind will get in there and it won't function that great as a windbreaker...who would've thought...  I live in Oklahoma and, similar to Kansas, we get tons of wind here, so I'm not just talking outta' my rear on this matter.

I also like it because it doesn't look like another North Face jacket that all the dudebros wear, nor does it look like a clone of one.

Most importantly, this jacket holds up to some serious wear-n-tear.  I do a lot of Geocaching and, like I mentioned about being in Oklahoma, there's a lot of thickets and underbrush I have to push through.  This jacket hasn't torn, the wooly parts haven't been disintegrated, etc.

Great quality, great function, nice style.  5 stars, Columbia.

product_title: DRI Duck Men's Outlaw Jacket
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    BUYER BEWARE!!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2017
review_body:
I am 5'11" 185 lbs. I ordered size Medium, as all of my other jackets are. The sleeves on this jacket are nearly 2" short of covering my wrists.
I JUST HAD TO PAY $13.50 to return this jacket!!!
In 10 years of shopping on Amazon, I have never had to pay return shipping on anything.
Therefore, I would advise ordering a size larger than normal, unless you have deep pockets. Which I do not. (nor does this jacket)
Other than my being gouged on the return costs as mentioned above, it seems to be a nice, thick, warm & Heavy jacket.
One last thing- the plastic bag it came in states that it was made in Bangladesh, not China as stated in the product description.

product_title: DRI Duck Men's Outlaw Jacket
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Ill-fitting jacket, no customer service at all for a return
review_title: Ill-fitting jacket, no customer service at all for a return
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2014
review_body: This was the oddest-fitting jacket I've ever seen. The XL size fits perfectly in the chest and trunk, but the sleeves end two to three inches above the wrist. I have normal-sized arms, an XL has been the size I've worn since I was 18, and that size has never failed to cover my arms until this jacket arrived. This is a lined jacket for all-weather winter use, and even with gloves, it would leave two inches of arm or shirt sleeve exposed. I asked for and immediately got a return authorization from Amazon. But two weeks after UPS tracking showed that the package arrived at the seller's door, no acknowledgement of receipt from the company, no notice of when or how a refund would be forthcoming, no communication at all, After 2 contact-the-seller emails went unacknowledged, I contacted Amazon, and they IMMEDIATELY processed a refund - out of their own pocket. I presume they will now go after the seller for the money. Meanwhile, I've resolved to NEVER patronize this seller again...

review_title: Well made jacket and nice design for work clothing
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2015
review_body:
Well made jacket and nice design for work clothing.  Not as nice as some of the pictures, though.  Material is fairly tough and happily not as stiff as I expected.  I would give it 5 stars except for the sizing.  I'm 6'1" tall with a 41" chest, 32" waist, and weigh 164lbs.  I usually take between a 34" and 35" sleeve in a shirt.  I bought this jacket in size medium.
The width of the jacket fit nicely, though there would be no room for layering.  However the sleeves were too short so I am returning it.  I wish the sleeves had been longer.  I recently bought two Carhartt jackets in medium, an the sleeves were plenty long enough for me.  I think Dri-duck needs to update its sizing, because men are taller than they were in the 70s and 80s, when medium was meant for a 33" sleeve, whereas these days many clothing manufacturers design medium to fit a 34" sleeve.  Too bad, I really would have liked to keep this jacket.

product_title: DRI Duck Men's Outlaw Jacket
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    A Tough, Well Constructed Jacket. Similar to a Carhartt. Suitable For Construction. Unsuitable For Casual Wear.
review_title: A Tough, Well Constructed Jacket. Similar to a Carhartt. Suitable For Construction. Unsuitable For Casual Wear.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2013
review_body:
I have been spending a great deal of time looking for a jacket to replace my decade old canvas cotton bomber-style jacket from Camel Collections.

This jacket, in the core elements, looks similar to my beloved bomber. It has a contrasting color collar, although in the case of this jacket, the collar is made of corduroy (not leather). It's a camel (khaki) color for the main body. It lacks the leather accents on the side pockets.

Well, since I had spent upwards of 15 hours in shopping malls and online searches, I decided to go with this jacket, and accept that I would never find another canvas cotton bomber that combined subtle accents of style with the comfort and toughness of canvas cotton.

So, I decided to roll the dice and hope that this jacket would be a suitable replacement for my old bomber.

Here are the Pros and Cons.

Pros

- The Canvas Cotton material feels tough, durable and breathable
- Just the right number of pockets (2 side, 1 breast, and 1 interior)
- Tough, well constructed zipper
- Large sleeves with ample room and a tight cuff which won't let wind through
- The nylon lining is warm and suitable for winter wear

Cons

- The jacket is a bit on the heavy side (as another commenter mentioned)
* The description of the jacket indicates it has a "bi-swing" back, which turns out to be extra "flaps" of material on the shoulder blades section of the jacket, which, in my opinion, look ridiculous
- The "drop tail" back looks a bit like the coat tails of a concert pianist, or the tail of a duck
- The description provided on the page uses terms like "bi-swing back" and "drop tail design" which the average consumer would be unfamiliar with and be unable to conjure up an image of. A picture of the back of the jacket should be provided (so I did. check out the customer photos for shots of the jackets back)

After having actually touched and seen the jacket up close, tried it out, and looked at in the mirror, I have come to the conclusion that this jacket is really NOT intended for casual wear. Rather, this jacket is designed, specifically, for guys who are working in construction and heavy industry.

The "bi-swing" back, with its flaps of extra material, does indeed provide additional freedom of movement for the arms and seems specifically designed with the vigorous movement required of guys working on the job site in mind.

As indicated in the title of the review, this jacket is very similar in construction, material and style to a Carhartt. It's a bit more stylish than the typical Carhartt, perhaps not unsuitable for being sufficiently flattering in appearance to ask out a pretty girl from the local building supply store, but it is definitely not suitable for taking said girl out for dinner and a movie.

Did I like this jacket? No. But I was expecting a jacket I could wear as a casual jacket for going out and about. I think this jacket is very suitable for construction, both contractors and journeymen.

I would be happy if I knew that this review helped guys to have it crystal clear to themselves that this jacket is NOT suitable for casual wear, and to purchase it if they are in the market for a warm jacket to use working on the job site, or shopping for building materials.

As for me, my quest for a stylish, canvas cotton bomber, continues.

P.S : On a quick side note, I purchased a very cool bomber from Mark's Work Wearhouse which looked like it had been taken from the closet of a WW II bomber pilot. Unfortunately, the material was PVC, and as I learned, PVC does NOT breathe at all. If you are looking for a jacket, don't buy PVC, unless you want to remove your jacket at a party and find that your shirt has unsightly sweat stains marring its appearance.

review_title: Carhartt beware, this is just as good.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2015
review_body:
I bought 2 of these jackets since I impressed with the quality and fit.

I first ordered the field khaki version. It's really a coyote brown color like a different reviewer mentioned.  Still looks good. The second jacket was tobacco in color.  I like the dark brown in tobacco better.

My deal was close to 50.00 dollars a piece if I recall off hand.  That is great price for the quality being on par with Carhartt.

Jackets are very sturdy.  Personally I don't think the material is too heavy for it's obvious intended use.  It's a work jacket that can pass for casual wear. These jackets will last for years.  Wish I lived a colder climate to get more use of the two jackets I bought. I''ll simply keep one for real work and the other for casual wear.

On that note, the styling is good.  I'm not the most fashionable person but this is a guys jacket.  Make no mistake, your not getting metro-sexual styling.  That's a plus.

The fit was excellent.  I'm broad shouldered and the jacket fits in an XL size.  Typically when I buy a suit, I buy 48 regular.  Based on the Dri-duck sizing chart, that seemed right on.

I definitely would recommend this jacket as a good buy.

    rugged, good looking, and well-made work coat
review_title: rugged, good looking, and well-made work coat
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2022
review_body: This is a great coat at a great price.  The duck material is thick and rugged, and the color is great.  The sleeves are also really well designed.  They have elastic fabric at your wrists that is covered by the sleeve.  This makes them really warm and great for working with your hands.  The coat is well sized to allow full movement.  The waist is curved, longer in the back that in the front.  This allows you to bend over to work and pick things up while not exposing your lower back.  The ONLY reason this coat didn't get a 5-star rating is because when zipped all the way up, the neck opening is too loose around your neck.  For me, this is not as warm as I would like on a cold winter day.  I would give the coat a 4.5-star rating if I could.

    Good replacement for my Carhartt Detroit jacket
review_title: Good replacement for my Carhartt Detroit jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2022
review_body:
Ordered this as a replacement for my older Carhartt Detroit jacket I’ve had for many years.
Overall very similar to the Detroit, less expensive and better overall quality and getting it shipped to me in a week instead of waiting until March for another Detroit jacket was a plus.
I work in construction and has kept me warm with a regular sweatshirt underneath and has held up to the daily work grind and yard work at my house.
Probably will stick with Dri Duck vs Carhartt going forward.
I ordered a small, I’m 5’9’’ 130-140 lbs fluctuates and this fits me perfectly. Not super large or baggy and enough room to wear hooded sweatshirt underneath. The bottom of the jacket comes down a little bit below the top of my back pocket.

product_title: DRI Duck Men's Outlaw Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Nice looking, fit well, YKK zippers, well thought out design. Real happy.
review_title: Nice looking, fit well, YKK zippers, well thought out design. Real happy.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2016
review_body:
I bought this jacket in Khaki, size medium. I'm 5'10", 160. Fit is perfect.

Khaki is an odd name for this color. I'd call it a lighter shade of tobbaco (its got brown and a bit of Army green hint to it). It's very good looking. Now, this is a working-man's jacket, so, yeah... it's heavier than a nylon yuppi's jacket. The bifold shoulders do the job properly and retract perfectly, the heavy 12oz canvas's weave is tight enough to minimize the wind cutting through it, the corduroy collar is comfy and doesn't sit tight on the neck (though if you zip all the way it wraps tight). The back of the coat has a bit of a drop-tail so when you bend over you don't expose above the belt but it's not excessive. There are two nicely done inside pockets (one's zipped for a cell or small note pad, the larger one is terrific for placing a flashlight or tools... whatever). It's also got an exterior zippered breast pocket. There's an elastic cuff in the sleeve, the inside has waffle-sewn insulation with a black nylon covering so it slides on and sits well over your work clothes. Lastly... this baby is using YKK zippers and they glide like a Caddy!

The only thing I hesitate on is whether it'll be warm enough with the 1/2 inch of insulation. It gets to -20F here so there's no cotton jacket in the world that handles that! So, I'm prepared to use layers. The good news is the jacket's wind resistant and provides enough roominess to wear at least good shirt and Polarguard sweater underneath.

I run a tow truck and need something that fits comfortable, is tough and washes without having to pamper it. I don't mind looking good while I'm at it. I can honestly say I was 100% happy with this jacket in every regard. And especially happy I didn't go with a Carhart for 3 times the price.

product_title: Striker Boys' Climate Durable Windproof Water-Resistant Insulated Outdoor Ice Fishing Jacket with Removable Hood
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great jacket but a little spendy
review_title: Great jacket but a little spendy
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
review_body:
Update: After spending the day getting snowed on for approximately 4 hours, the jacket was starting to soak with water. The claim that these jackets are waterproof is a bit misleading and once I dug a little further into the Striker Ice website I came across their explanation. Bottom line these jackets are not waterproof by definition. They are to a point. The waterproof rating is 1/5th that of Gortex. They also claim the zippers to be waterproof yet the pockets did have some water in them. A jacket at this price range to me should have better protection, but maybe I am just asking too much.

Love this jacket. I haven't had a chance to really test it and I pretty much use the liner or the shell. The liner is good for the mid 40s for general use. I have worn the shell by itself as low as 27 degrees and though I could feel it a little bit in the sleeves, my core area stayed comfortable with just a t-shirt. My biggest gripe is for a 4xl the sleeves are short when my arms are extended. Maybe that's by design. I dont use this jacket for it's intended use (ice fishing) so maybe there's a reason. I have a long torso and this is one of the few jackets that fits me good. Only other thing I'd like to see is this jacket made in the US and not china. I'd expect to pay 320.00 for a US made jacket but not a Chinese jacket.

review_title: Fit wrong(small), pockets too small, wind cuff not elastic, not wicking, smell sticks.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2015
review_body:
Its warm but it doesn't let the sweat out... after a few min. I was all wet inside.
The size is all wrong, I have another salomon, L size as well. This one is either too small or the fit is just wrong.
The stomach area is ok, the shoulders are too tight/narrow. I can't move my hands freely. Seems like around the arm/shoulder it gonna tear apart.
The pockets are way too small to be usable.
The wind-block cuffs are not elastic so air does come through the sleeves.
I usually wear M-L sizes, XL sizes make me look fat and are not comfortable. Fit-built is plain wrong on this item.
I noticed that if I don't wash it after 1 day it will start to smell... even when using deodorant... it seems it doesnt have anti-odor/anti-bacteria deodorant built-into it like other products I have.
Too bad. I really love this color :(

product_title: Salomon Men's Insulated Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    like most other Salomon jackets I have tried it is ...
review_title: like most other Salomon jackets I have tried it is ...
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2015
review_body:
I have the hooded version of this jacket.

 like most other Salomon jackets I have tried it is designed for a slim/athletic build (if you do not have this type build, then this is not for you).

It is a very comfortable jacket, (albeit with slightly longer arms). The collar is fleece lines, as are the pockets. The sleeve cuffs are elastic and very comfortable and prevent drafts going up sleeve. The synthetic fill is warm, but comfortable (not too warm, in my opinion).  I find the jacket breathable, and use it as a mid-layer for very cold days under a shell, and as a stand-alone jacket on mild fall or early spring days.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Grade Max Hooded Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I love the jacket
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2014
review_body:
First watch the item for a bit, Amazon is all over the place with the price on this jacket. I ordered an XL in Abyss for $39.70 and currently it is $62.94. Beyond that, I love the jacket. I was in Chicago recently for work, walking around at night is was under 40 degrees and very windy. This jacket performed very well and kept me warm and I did not feel the wind on my core. I love Columbia products and have a variety of their clothing. This performs well and is probably still a great deal at $60, but was a steal at under $40. Next week I will be taking it to Denver and the expected lows are as low as 18 degrees and I am confident I will be fine with this as my top layer.

The omni-heat radiant barrier is a nice touch but my 8 year old daughter refers to this my "disco-ball jacket" and it is pretty accurate -LOL. The lining is a micro dot pattern of shiny-reflective thermal dots. Again, given my experience in Chicago last week I could careless about the nickname.

The sleeves can bunch a bit if you are wearing layers, it just takes a second to adjust them, and is not a deal-breaker in my opinion.  The jacket runs large, but I like that feature as I am going to be wearing layers often anyway if I need this and I want my top layer to run a bit larger to go over everything. If you are going to run around in this and just a t-shirt, then you will notice the size a bit more.

The only thing I wish was different was the hood. I will never wear it and wish it was just a standard collar like their fleece or other jackets, however again at $40, I really have zero complaints.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Grade Max Hooded Jacket
reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Watch out there are problems.
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2015
review_body:
I ordered this jacket for myself Off season in July of 2014.  The description said it was wool, I was surprised when it came it looked like a nice, hooded sweater. The fit was great (XXL) kept me warm down to about 20 degrees. It's thin, light weight comes down to about the middle of my butt and seals great here as well as velcro sleves which are a little long.  The inside is reflective and looks like the extremely material they make ladies evening gowns out of - kind of  looks like a mirror (reflective material) I'm sure it helps reflect body heat to keep you warm.  The material doesn't seem to chafe bare skin

Here's the problem after a few months of wearing - it looks awful, it even has a wore out appearance. The outer wool is now COVERED with those little balls of fibers like an old sweater gets.  I see why they offered it at such a great price less than forty bucks.  Now it becomes my yard raking-mowing jacket instead of the great looking Columbia jacket I'd hoped for. Good thing I didn't have to pay full price.

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Grade Max Hooded Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good jacket with a couple of design flaws
review_title: Good jacket with a couple of design flaws
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2014
review_body:
UPDATE:  10 years later ... As I mentioned in my original review, the sleeve liner catches on your clothes, and eventually the seam gave out.  Interestingly, the zipper also failed.  I stopped wearing it a couple of years ago when these things failed, but then as I was going through my closet, I came across this jacket and remembered the warranty.  I thought, "what the hell" and I sent it in.  Much to my astonishment, the jacket came back to me a couple of days ago and somebody had literally restitched the seams that came apart and they had sewn a new zipper into the jacket.  I had to come on here and increase my rating for this jacket, because I am so impressed that the company hires people to fix clothing that has failed - not just send out a new item.  I am still completely flabbergasted that they believe in their clothing so much that they think it is worth hiring somebody to fix it.  Boy do I wish more companies were like this!  I am still not crazy about the design flaws, but it's hard to fault them when they are willing to fix the jacket.  Fair enough - it's been 10 years, but I'll keep wearing this jacket as long as they keep fixing it.  Game on!  GO COLUMBIA!

I like Columbia because of their return policy and the quality of their product.  What I'm not crazy about are the sleeve liners, which move independently of the sleeve and catch on clothes.  It makes putting the jacket on a challenge because you have to try to get all the layers (the shell, the liner, and the long sleeve shirt you are wearing) to behave themselves so that you don't end up with the various layers bunched up and uncomfortable.  It's not a deal breaker, but it seems like a design flaw to me.  Also, the zipper doesn't lay well--it's like there is too much zipper for the material that is attached to it, so it creates unattractive waves in the material.  I know this sounds negative, but I do like the jacket!

Mountain Hardwear Men's Stratus Range Full Zip
Mountain Hardwear Men's Stratus Range Full Zip
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good 2nd layer mid layer piece - without a bulky hood to get in the way
review_title: Good 2nd layer mid layer piece - without a bulky hood to get in the way
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2022
review_body:
Fit: In dress shirts, I wear a size 15 32/33 shirt. In suits/sport coats I wear a size 38 short. I ordered this in a size small.  Shoulder fit is good, chest fit is a little snug (good for a 2nd layer IMO), stomach area is a bit lose on me, sleeve length is PERFECT (not too long like on so many layering pieces). Collar fit on me is good and would be for a 15.5 neck size too.

Why I ordered: Years ago, I bought a MH Monkey Man 2nd layer "jacket", my first piece with the grid lining - and I fell in love with that piece and it's effectiveness/performance so much, that I bought the same for my son and daughter. I have since found the grid fleece interiors for a 1st or 2nd layer to perform far better than a typical fleece interior - better wicking away while also holding heat (without feeling wet).  What I like better about this piece vs. the Monkey Man: smoother exterior fabric makes for easier layering (putting on and taking off) and also the fact that there is not a hood that is uncomfortable after putting on subsequent layers (I never need a hood on a layering piece - that's what my outer layer or a hat is for - IMO).

I am a layerer, typically wearing 4 layers (base, 2, 3, outer shell). This piece is on the moderate or thinner side as a 2nd layer (this is neither good or bad, just that it is what it is). It will hold/trap heat, but also wick and breath due to the grid pattern (my experience). On super frigid days (ie. <5 degree F), I would opt for one of my heavier 2nd layer pieces (or wear an insulated vs. shell outer layer).

Overall - the fit is very good for my body and preference. I like the look and comfort of the "jacket" and am glad that I purchased it as another option for a 2nd layer piece.

I've owned a fair amount of Mountain Hardware products over the past 15+ years. Sleeping bags & pads, pants, tops, jackets. Overall, I've been exceptionally happy with the quality of their products. But I have heard that more recently, their quality has diminished (becoming more like The North Face - away from performance and more towards fashion). I can see a little bit of this in this piece, the seems on the sleeves are a bit larger than they could be - but of course, going smaller and lighter would add to the cost (if this is of utmost importance to you - look at the Arc'teryx 2nd layer pieces).

Mountain Hardware has excellent after sale customer service. I am in the process of sending in a 10+ year old soft shell winter jacket where the zipper has started to come open in the middle. I contacted them asking what the price would be and was informed the cost would be $30, but that it will likely be covered under warranty. Outside of this zipper issue (which to be honest, I don't think they should fix for free for a 10 year old jacket), the rest of the jacket is in like new condition - exceptionally pleased with it's performance and the other products I've owned from Mountain Hardware.

Sorry this is such a long review for what is really a pretty moderately priced mid layer piece, but for others who want more than just the normal - loved it, hated it, didn't fit, etc. I've tried to provide useful info.

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    February Snow in Manhattan, NY (25 - 35 deg)
review_title: February Snow in Manhattan, NY (25 - 35 deg)
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2011
review_body:
February Snow in Manhattan, NY (25 - 35 deg)
Feb 8, 2011

I wore it for 3 straight days, Feb 3rd to Feb 6th, 2011, in NYC, before returning to NC. I purchased this with the intention of not wearing a heavy coat in Manhattan, NY, which I never did. I wore long underwear, blue jeans, wool socks, t shirt, thin wool sweater, and this jacket, along with scarf and gloves. I did not freeze in 25 to 35 degree weather, but neither was I warm. When the wind blew, I really felt it on my arms. At this point, I shivered and was not warm. Hence, it cannot replace a heavy coat. But without the wind, I managed to stay warm. The style is great! I look professional in very a sporty jacket. The fit is perfect. I am 5'10", 185 lbs with a 33" waist. The reflective technology (inner lining) is suspect.

For the look, fit, and versatility, this is must have jacket.

I use this for:

Rain, light wind, cool weather, not cold weather

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Nice, but does not fit
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2010
review_body: This seems like a well made jacket (I can't vouch for the new "omni-heat" lining - I never wore it outside), but unfortunately I had to return it.  This jacket runs small.  And not just proportionately small, but in an oddball way.  It almost seems like this was patterned for women and just upsized.  I ordered an XL, and the sleeves and hem were the right length, but the shoulders, upper arms, and areas around the armpits are all very very tight.  This is while trying it on with just a t-shirt - not good for a jacket that is marketed for cold weather and as having a new patent pending ultra warm lining - I usually wear something more substantial tha a t-shirt (base layer & fleece or long sleeve shirt) in winter.  That being said, it is attractive, the innovative lining seems like it will work, so I will try and re-order in 2XL, and see if it fits (hopefully the sleeves won't be too long, with the hem below my crotch).  I'll update the review accordingly.

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Not as warm as I expected
review_title: Not as warm as I expected
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2011
review_body:
I put it on to get the mail as soon as I got it home.  I wore a t-shirt and a flannel LS shirt under it.  It was 42F outside with very slight air movement.  As soon as I stepped outside into the garage I could feel the cool fabric on my back and arms.  The reflective liner may work but it needs an insulation layer to trap heat and to keep the cool surface of the material off your body.  No extra warmth feeling at all.

I expect if I were hiking or moving more vigorously it would have kept me warmer but then so would any other cheaper jacket.  A really expensive rain coat.

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Highly Over-rated Gimmick!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2012
review_body: I purchased this jacket after reading the manufacturer's claims about the high performance of their new technology. Boy was I disappointed. The jacket is not any more effective than a good fleece pullover. I don't know where these guys do their so-called testing, but I tested this jacket for a month in Stockholm in the early spring last year and at about +7 degrees Centigrade it was pathetic. I had to use an insulated jacket over it to manage. In fact, there wasn't much difference between wearing the two jackets together and just wearing the insulated jacket by itself! Also, the velcro straps on the cuffs of the sleeves cut into your wrists and catch on other clothes, sometimes damaging them. Very over-rated and over-priced! Just a gimmick!

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Perfect for the Cold Colorado Air
review_title: Perfect for the Cold Colorado Air
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2011
review_body:
Unlike many of the other people reviewing this jacket, I found it to fit superbly. I am 6'3", 180 lbs, and I ordered a large. It was a perfectly snug fit that kept me warm during the harsh Colorado winter. It's space-blanket liner does just as advertised, keeps you pretty darn warm even when it's 30 degrees outside and the wind is blowing in your face. The pockets are soft and nice, and I like the breast pocket for keeping my valuables. The charcoal grey was a nice color, and less tan than the picture on Amazon shows. It gets a 4 star rating simply because it was a little stiff. It had nothing to do with the fit, but the material. It didn't want to move very much, and the hand holes were far too big. Maybe I just didn't use it enough, but it did almost feel like I imagine a straightjacket would.

I know that sounds grim but it really is an awesome jacket and if you live somewhere really cold, it's definitely worth trying.

product_title: Columbia Men's Thermodynamic Softshell
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Perfect jacket for college guy
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2010
review_body: My college-aged son suggested this specific jacket after "window shopping" on line. He had not actually seen this item in person, but liked the features as described. He needed a warm but light-weight jacket. I trusted the Columbia name, but rather than buying it directly from Columbia (the link he provided me), I found it on Amazon (same color, correct size)for much less in cost. He was absolutely thrilled and had an opportunity to try it out right away as he ventured out into the snow on a frigid night to go sledding. He returned singing the praises of this jacket which comfortably kept him warm and dry. He is very slender and the fit is perfect on him. A great, quality jacket; especially when purchased through Amazon for a significantly better price!

product_title: Columbia Men's Lush Plush Jacket
reviews:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Very strange cut and material
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2012
review_body:
This claims to be a men's jacket, but when mine arrived I could not put it on because my arms would not fit through the sleeves.  I should emphasize that I am not a body builder.  My hands would not go more than half way down the sleeve and would not come close to fitting through the end.  There is no elastic cuff so there is no give.  I normally wear a medium (small in some items) and the tag claimed this was a medium.

I notice that other reviews are from women.  Maybe this thing is cut for a slender woman who's trying to be stylish even though it says "men's."  I bought it to keep me warm in the outdoors and I really don't care about what some magazine says is stylish.  I would often wear it over some other garment.  This isn't possible when a bare arm won't can't be forced through the sleeve!

It is lined with a strange reflective material that looks like aluminum foil.  The effect is startling but I can't say if it works since I couldn't put the jacket on.  The jacket also has some panels that are just fabric and lack any insulation other than the foil stuff.  It seems that this would not be very warm.  Since I couldn't put the thing on and it's 98 degrees outside right now I can't test that.

product_title: Columbia Men's Lush Plush Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    LOVE this jacket!!!
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2013
review_body:
I'm unclear what the first reviews are talking about - - this review is for the Columbia women's jacket pictured above.
I am so in love with this jacket that I'm buying two more; one in a different color and one as a backup!
Columbia is using new technology on the inside of their jackets that uses your own warmth to insulate and warm you.
And it really works!
In addition, I love the plush feel of the outside of the jacket. Most plush jackets are shapeless, you sacrifice style for comfort, but this jacket has both.
The stitching and the seams are flawless. It has great shoulders and looks amazing from behind.
It runs a little small. I'm 5 foot eight and a size 6, and I wear the large so that I can layer other clothing under it.
For cold women who want to gorgeous jacket - - you can't go wrong with this one!

product_title: Columbia Men's Lush Plush Jacket
reviews:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    So Plush
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2013
review_body: I gave this product five stars because I love it so much! The exterior is sooo soft. The inside is cool, I haven't worn it outside long enough to determine if the "omni-heat thermo tech" stuff is any good, but I like to layer any way. I purchased it in a large because I read all the reviews and everyone said they run small. I checked this jacket out on so many websites and some listed the model's height & weight and all said the model was wearing a large. I put this jacket on and I look like a turtle. I am a 5'3" Asian girl 125lbs. A lot of people said they usually wear a size small too and purchasing a large was a good fit. I like that it has the hem drawstrings to tighten at the waist, but it didn't tighten all that much. Maybe because I purchased it so big. Overall I love this jacket. I ordered a medium to see how the fit is. Very happy with it :)

product_title: Columbia Sportswear Men's Smooth Pursuit Softshell Jacket
reviews:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great light jacket - but doesn't shed rain that well
review_title: Great light jacket - but doesn't shed rain that well
reviewer_country_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2014
review_body:
Update 8/25/2014
Dropped 2 stars.  The jacket is no longer shedding rain that well.  Columbia has offered to replace it as they have lifetime warranties on their products so this is why I'm giving 3 stars, or I'd be giving it 2 stars.  I just haven't sent it in.  The other solution is to reapply waterproofing to it, but I shouldn't have had to do that within a single season of purchasing it.  I'm probably going to have them replace it, but I need to cover shipping so I haven't decided yet.

Original Review 4/5/2014:
I was looking for a jacket that was light but able to shed Seattle Spring rain and winds, looks casual and stylish without looking too sporty or like a shell. I wanted a go-to jacket for everyday wear to take to restaurants, walk the town or to wear to church.  I wanted a jacket that wasn't too warm, but not too light that it offered no protection to the elements.  It took me a while to finally settle on this jacket simply because I was looking for one with a hood.  I finally saw this on sale for an amazing price and couldn't pass it up and I'm glad I didn't.  It is perfect for what I was looking for.

I don't wear the collar up like in the photo, I wear it down and my daughter says it looks great that way.
The Omni-Heat only covers the inside back and arms so you don't see the shiny silver if you wear the jacket unzipped which is great.
There's enough room to wear a long sleeved shirt without the arms feeling too tight, I'm able to move around in the jacket without feeling restricted.

I purchased the Buffalo colored version and when I received the jacket I thought they sent me the wrong color.  Under my house lights, I could have swore it was a dark forest green so I thought I was sent the "Moss" colored jacket.  I thought it looked fine, but I was wanting the brown as pictured.  I then showed my wife and she said she wasn't sure what color it was, kinda looked gray, or dark green, or maybe even brown... then I took the jacket outside in the daylight and it was definitely dark brown.  Totally weird, but kinda cool.  Still not sure it was the Buffalo, I went to the Columbia website and lo and behold the color there for Buffalo was darker than what is portrayed on Amazon, but it does kinda look like that color in the sunlight. So just beware.

The zippered outside hand pockets are very spacious and I love how they zip up, so you can keep things secure without fear of stuff falling out, though I doubt they would even unzipped as the pockets are deep.
The button breast pockets are also great and useful, but much smaller than the hand pockets.  Good for ticket stubs, parking passes, etc.
The only thing I miss is an inside pocket, it doesn't have one.  So the breast pockets get more use than they otherwise would.
